column17: A militant was captured by security forces on 20 December after a violent skirmish with an armed group in Ait Dahmane in the Ammal region southeast of Boumerdes. A Kalashnikov-type weapon belonging to the militant was recovered by the soldiers. The skirmish occurred as the security forces were conducting a search in that region. The militants capture was facilitated by the fact that he was wounded. The rest of the armed group was successful in fleeing, according to the same source.

Riots broke out in districts covered by the programme to re-house 10,000 families. on 25 December, inhabitants of Les Palmiers district, in the municipality of Bachdjarah blocked the Oued Ouchayah tunnel to traffic for hours, in both directions, and there were clashes with the forces of order. Residents feel they are excluded from resettlement programs as their homes fall into a state of disrepair and unsanitary living conditions.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Two AQLMI militants are killed and five wounded in a shootout with soldiers. The operation, staged in Djemaa bni Habibi commune, about 40 km eastern Jijel, aimed to wipe out strongholds of the militants.

Clashes have taken place in the city of Palmiers, Laaquiba and Baraki because of re-housing. In Baraki, the residents of Hai Al-Baraka have still not subsided, despite the vague promises by local authorities. Residents feel they are excluded from resettlement programs as their homes fall into a state of disrepair and unsanitary living conditions.

Clashes have taken place in the city of Palmiers, Laaquiba and Baraki because of re-housing. In Sidi-Mhamed, the residents of Laaquiba went out into the street on the night of Monday to Tuesday [27 to 28 December] to express their anger. Residents feel they are excluded from resettlement programs as their homes fall into a state of disrepair and unsanitary living conditions. People living in these areas burnt tires and threw stones and Molotov cocktails at police, who responded with tear gas and arrests.

In the city of Palmiers, clashes between demonstrators and security forces continued on the night of Monday to Tuesday [27 to 28 December] when young people threw from the top of a building a bottle of butane gas on the police station located in the former middle school. Residents feel they are excluded from resettlement programs as their homes fall into a state of disrepair and unsanitary living conditions.
53 people are injured and 29 arrested during a protest over inadequate housing.

Protests over inadequate housing spread to other suburbs of Algiers, with protesters taking to the streets against the lack of housing in Ennakhil, Diar el Babor and Cervantes. People living in these areas burnt tires and threw stones and Molotov cocktails at police, who responded with tear gas and arrests.
Security forces kill a member of a terror organization and wound two others during a raid on their compound.

A homemade bomb buried in the ground exploded on 2 January in Kadiria, located 20 kilometres to the east of Lakhdaria, in the wilaya of Bouira. The attack occurred as a freight train passed through coming from Algiers and going to Beni Mansour. The explosion did not result in human losses though there were material damages.
Demonstrators blocked roads on 3 January in Tipaza, west of the capital, in protest against food prices and difficult living conditions.
More than a hundred docker workers in the port of Algiers, observed a work stoppage on 4 January to protest against new measures relating to overtime compensation and shifts.
On 4 January, young rioters, some of which came from out of the stadium Bologhine, burned tires and chanted anti-government slogans in the Bab El Oued district.

Demonstration took place on 5 January in several districts of Algiers, in protest at food price hikes. The demonstrations took place in La Place des Martyrs (Casbah), Belcourt, Bachdjarrah, Bab El Oued and Staoueli (all in Algiers Province), as well in Djelfa, in southern Algeria.

Demonstration took place on 5 January in several districts of Algiers, in protest at food price hikes. The demonstrations took place in La Place des Martyrs (Casbah), Belcourt, Bachdjarrah, Bab El Oued and Staoueli (all in Algiers Province), as well in Djelfa, in southern Algeria.

Demonstration took place on 5 January in several districts of Algiers, in protest at food price hikes. The demonstrations took place in La Place des Martyrs (Casbah), Belcourt, Bachdjarrah, Bab El Oued and Staoueli (all in Algiers Province), as well in Djelfa, in southern Algeria.
Rioters gather in the streets over the rise of food prices, unemployment, and a perceived deterioration of basic government services, clashing with police. Police guard mosques.
Protesters gather in the streets over the rise of food prices, unemployment, and a perceived deterioration of basic government services.
Security forces kill a militant and wound several others after they surround them.
On the road to Bordj El Kiffan, young people erected barricades with concrete blocks. Armed with iron bars, they attacked motorists. No reports of injuries.
On 5 January in Dergana, rioters burned vehicles, erected barricades and cut roads.

Demonstration took place on 5 January in several districts of Algiers, in protest at food price hikes. The demonstrations took place in La Place des Martyrs (Casbah), Belcourt, Bachdjarrah, Bab El Oued and Staoueli (all in Algiers Province), as well in Djelfa, in southern Algeria.

Rioters gather in the streets over the rise of food prices, unemployment, and a perceived deterioration of basic government services, clashing with police. Dozens of youths hurled stones at a police station in the Bab el Oued area, set alight several shops and barricaded roads with flaming tyres.

Protesters gather in the streets over the rise of food prices, unemployment, and a perceived deterioration of basic government services. In Oran, youth blocked the road with burning tires and clashed with police forces.

Demonstration took place on 5 January in several districts of Algiers, in protest at food price hikes. The demonstrations took place in La Place des Martyrs (Casbah), Belcourt, Bachdjarrah, Bab El Oued and Staoueli (all in Algiers Province), as well in Djelfa, in southern Algeria.

Demonstration took place on 5 January in several districts of Algiers, in protest at food price hikes. The demonstrations took place in La Place des Martyrs (Casbah), Belcourt, Bachdjarrah, Bab El Oued and Staoueli (all in Algiers Province), as well in Djelfa, in southern Algeria.
Protesters gather in the streets over the rise of food prices, unemployment, and a perceived deterioration of basic government services.

Rioters block roads and torch police stations and other government buildings in several towns in reaction to rising food costs and high unemployment. In many cases rocks are thrown at shops and other privately owned buildings. Over several days three died, 800 were injured and 1,000 arrests were made.
Rioters torch a car dealership to protest the increased cost of living.

Rioters assembled in the Bab El Oued neighborhood of Algiers, arm themselves with iron bars, and burn tires in protest of the increased cost of living. The protests were over unemployment in the underprivleged Bab el Oued area. Rioters torched a car dealership to protest the increased cost of living.
Protesters contract a barricade on a major highway linking two large towns.
Protesters barricade a road and vandalize much of the area surrounding it.
Protesters barricade a major road.

In the suburb of Bordj El Bahri east of Algiers, rioters set fire to a post office. Young inhabitant also cut the road to Ain Taya and that down to Matifou. They set up makeshift barricades with dumpsters and tires they burned.

Rioters block roads and torch police stations and other government buildings in several towns in reaction to rising food costs and high unemployment. In many cases rocks are thrown at shops and other privately owned buildings. Over several days three died, 800 were injured and 1,000 arrests were made.

Rioters block roads and torch police stations and other government buildings in several towns in reaction to rising food costs and high unemployment. In many cases rocks are thrown at shops and other privately owned buildings. Over several days three died, 800 were injured and 1,000 arrests were made.

Rioters block roads and torch police stations and other government buildings in several towns in reaction to rising food costs and high unemployment. In many cases rocks are thrown at shops and other privately owned buildings. Over several days three died, 800 were injured and 1,000 arrests were made. Authorities sent in ""a large number of convoys of anti-riot police.

Rioters block roads and torch police stations and other government buildings in several towns in reaction to rising food costs and high unemployment. In many cases rocks are thrown at shops and other privately owned buildings. Over several days three died, 800 were injured and 1,000 arrests were made. Authorities sent in ""a large number of convoys of anti-riot police.

Rioters block roads and torch police stations and other government buildings in several towns in reaction to rising food costs and high unemployment. In many cases rocks are thrown at shops and other privately owned buildings. Over several days three died, 800 were injured and 1,000 arrests were made.

Rioters block roads and torch police stations and other government buildings in several towns in reaction to rising food costs and high unemployment. In many cases rocks are thrown at shops and other privately owned buildings. Over several days three died, 800 were injured and 1,000 arrests were made.
Rioters assemble in the El Harrach neighborhood of Algiers, and in other parts of the city.
On 6 January, in the centre of the town of Ighzer Amokrane, demonstrations degenerated into a riot where the anti-riot forces that blocked the road resorted to teargas.

The province of Chlef saw protests on 6 January. In Chettia, protesters protested against soaring prices and the delay in the management of prefabricated folder. Rioters blocked the RN 19 connecting to Tenes Chlef and alleys of part of the city of Chettia, forcing users to take other routes to reach their homes. Note that this road was quickly reopened to traffic by police.

In the locality of El Kerma, Oran, a small group of young people blocked traffic on te national road Oran-Oued Tlelat. The arrival of reinforcements from the intervention group of the National Gendarmerie drove off the young demonstrators. Part of the office of the showroom of Toyota was ransacked by protesters who threw objects on the windows.

In Dergana, youths set a town hall alight over price hikes for milk, sugar and flour and amid simmering frustration that Algerias abundant gas-and-oil resources have not translated into broader prosperity.
In the suburb of Rouiba, youths set fire to tires and danced around them, chanting ""Bring us sugar!"" Others tore down street signs and smashed streetlights with iron bars.

Protests took place in Ras El Oued, the second city of the province of Bordj Bou Arreridj 6 January. Several public buildings were vandalized by young people protesting against the high cost of living.
In the province of Blida (50-km south of Algiers), protests were followed by acts of vandalism in many bordering regions.

Over the course of several days more than 300 police are injured, 800 rioters injured, 1,000 arrested, and eight dead (some report three dead, others eleven) throughout the country. As a result of the protests the government suspended several duties on staple goods. The dead were reported in Bou Ismail and Msila and Boumerdes provinces.

Over the course of several days more than 300 police are injured, 800 rioters injured, 1,000 arrested, and eight dead (some report three dead, others eleven) throughout the country. As a result of the protests the government suspended several duties on staple goods. The dead were reported in Bou Ismail and Msila and Boumerdes provinces.
Twenty-two people, including 10 children, were admitted for first aid treatment in the province of Constantina after protests erupted on 7 January.
A wave of protests, riots and vandalism occurred in municipalities in Guelma on 7 January.
Riots were reported in some areas of Skikda and Batna (Barika).
Riots were reported in some areas of Skikda and Batna (Barika).
Two gendarmes wounded in car bomb explosion near their headquarters. An exchange of fire ensured between the gendarmes and militants that were positioned on the heights of a hill.
Two are dead when police clash with rioters who were protesting rising food prices. Many others wounded, including police. Teargas implemented.
On 7 January, a body was found in a hotel in Tidjelabine in Boumerdes, which was burned down by rioters.

Over the course of several days more than 300 police are injured, 800 rioters injured, 1,000 arrested, and eight dead (some report three dead, others eleven) throughout the country. As a result of the protests the government suspended several duties on staple goods. The dead were reported in Bou Ismail and Msila and Boumerdes provinces.
Rioters protesting high unemployment and rising food costs clash with police in multiple cities and towns.
Rioters protesting high unemployment and rising food costs clash with police in multiple cities and towns. The riot took place in the Belcourt District of the capital.
Rioters protesting high unemployment and rising food costs clash with police in multiple cities and towns.
Rioters protesting high unemployment and rising food costs clash with police in multiple cities and towns.
On 7 January, protests took place in the Algiers district of Belcourt over rising food prices.
A cost of living protester is shot and killed by police.
Young people from the district of El Djebbi in Bordj Bou Arerridj tried to attack the central police station on 7 January by throwing stones, they were disbanded by anti-riot forces.
Rioters destroy buildings and other private property in protest over increased living conditions.
Rioters protesting high unemployment and rising food costs clash with police in multiple cities and towns.
Rioters protesting high unemployment and rising food costs clash with police in multiple cities and towns. One protester reported dead.
Rioters protesting high unemployment and rising food costs clash with police in multiple cities and towns.
Unemployment rioters clash with police. One dead.
Rioters protesting high unemployment and rising food costs clash with police in multiple cities and towns.
Rioters protesting high unemployment and rising food costs clash with police in multiple cities and towns.
Rioters protesting high unemployment and rising food costs clash with police in multiple cities and towns.
Unemployment rioters severely damaging government buildings, including the state-run gas authority.
The security forces managed to defeat an attempt by rioters to access the new shopping center in Bab Ezzouar. Clashes between youth and police erupted.
On 7 January in Baraki, the Continental Electronics factory suffered extensive damage after being attacked by young people living close to loot whatever is inside.
On the 7 January, violence resumed in Bordj El Bahri and Bordj El Kiffan.
On the 7 January, violence resumed in Bordj El Bahri and Bordj El Kiffan.
A local was attacked by rioters in the afternoon of 7 January. This attack happens against a backdrop of riots over the price of basic foodstuffs.
One is dead when unemployment protesters clash with police. The man was hit by a bullet in Ain Lahdjel in the MSila region, 300 kilometres (180 miles) southeast of Algiers during riots.
Unemployment rioters demonstrators gather in Laghouat.
One is dead when unemployment protesters clash with police.
Two are dead when police clash with rioters who were protesting rising food prices. Many others wounded, including police.
Protests spread to Constantine, in eastern Algeria on 8 January, where youths faced down police in skirmishes.
A 65-year-old taxi driver died in hospital after inhaling tear gas on 8 January, during clashes between rioters and security forces in the eastern town of Annaba.
One rioter is dead in Boumerdes following a clash with police.
In the town of Aokas, riots broke out on 8 January, with rioters destroying the post office, the headquarters of the ADE, that of Sonelgaz agency and the premises of Algeria Telecom (AT).
The capital of Bejaia, rioters targeted the BNA agency Ihaddaden, located at Edimco, setting it alight on 8 January. The attackers managed to seize and move the safe.

In Sidi Bel Abbes on 8 January riots had grown and the rioters targeted state buildings. The most affected districts are Sidi Djilali and Benhamouda. The rioters composed of youth and minors vandalized, broken, burned many buildings. They attacked shops to steal televisions, satellite receivers and other equipment. Rioters clasheed with police officers, injuring five and leading to 60 arrests.

In Sidi Bel Abbes on 8 January riots had grown and the rioters targeted state buildings. The most affected districts are Sidi Djilali and Benhamouda. The rioters composed of youth and minors vandalized, broken, burned many buildings. They attacked shops to steal televisions, satellite receivers and other equipment. Rioters clasheed with police officers, injuring five and leading to 60 arrests.
In Souk El-Thenine, the headquarters of the CPA was looted. Rioters attacked police and the local brigade of the national gendarmerie.

Clashes between rioters and security forces continued. In Tiaret Tizi Ouzou, a fourth person, a young man died from a gunshot last Saturday evening as he tried with his father to defend them against a group of rioters.
In Annaba (600-km east of Algiers), a group of young people blocked the main road in the district of Didouche-Mourad.
Members of the military shoot and kill a wanted ""militant"" and recover an AK-47.

In Akbou, a committee of civil society, brought together local elected officials, civil society activists and elders from the region to hold a day of protest to ""stop the destruction of public property and provide adequate guidance to the legitimate social demands initially expressed by the protesters"".
In the town of Amizour rioters continued to ransack the house of Malek-Bouguermouh culture and agency of the Popular Credit of Algeria CPA.
The mayor of Barbacha and local associations staged a protest march to denounce the vandalism from riots and called for better regulation of the food market.

On 9 January, the university doors of Bouzareah and others were closed in the face of students who wanted to demonstrate peacefully. In spite of the ban, the Nedjma Association held a peaceful rally inside the university, its organizers gathered a few dozen students around them, under the supervision of security and police officers.
In Darguina, people armed with clubs prevented citizens from setting fire to the headquarters of the PCA.
In the province of Constantine, initial protests occurred in the city of Khroub.
At el-kseur, several public buildings including the headquarters of the daira were burned and violent clashes broke out between demonstrators and security forces.
Riots reported in Kherrata, Sidi Aich, Tazmalt and Ouzellaguen communes of Bejaia.
Riots reported in Kherrata, Sidi Aich, Tazmalt and Ouzellaguen communes of Bejaia.
In Melbou, Bejaia, rioters clashed with police forces.
Riots reported in Kherrata, Sidi Aich, Tazmalt and Ouzellaguen communes of Bejaia.
In Souk El-Thenine, the tax office and the headquarters of the ADE were attached by rioters on 9 January.
Riots reported in Kherrata, Sidi Aich, Tazmalt and Ouzellaguen communes of Bejaia.

Acts of violence and vandalism continued on 9 January for the fourth consecutive day in some localities of the province of Bejaia. All roads are still blocked. The town of Tichy, hitherto relatively unscathed, was the scene of violent riots that pitted young demonstrators against the police. Inside the police station of the city center, police were forced to shoot warning shots to repel attackers trying to invade their neighborhoods. The local tax office and the headquarters of the Algerian des Eaux (ADE) were looted and torched by rioters. RN 9 was consequently cut off to traffic.
Following a self-immolation, a hundred residents of Boukhadra came out into the street for a protest action. But the demonstrators were broken up by the gendarmerie.
A man commits suicide by fire after police confiscated his vegetable cart. His protest was in a larger since a protest of governmental policies.

column7: RCD: Rally for Culture and Democracy Party
column17: Police broke up a banned pro-democracy demonstration, organized by the opposition political party, leaving 19 people injured, including seven police officers and six arrested. The demonstration was in defiance of Algerias recent ban on public gatherings.

column7: RCD: Rally for Culture and Democracy Party
column17: Police broke up a banned pro-democracy demonstration, organized by the opposition political party, leaving 5 people dead, 19 people injured, including seven police officers and six arrested. The demonstration was in defiance of Algerias recent ban on public gatherings.

column7: RCD: Rally for Culture and Democracy Party
column17: More than 10,000 protesters organised by RCD marched against authorities in Algerias northeastern city of Bejaia in favor of governmental change.

column7: RCD: Rally for Culture and Democracy Party
column17: Members of the RCD opposition party march in favor of a regime change.
Two soldiers were seriously wounded by the explosion of a homemade bomb on 31 January as a truck drove in Bir Al Ater area, in the Tebessa region.
Two soldiers were seriously wounded by the explosion of a homemade bomb on 31 January as a truck drove in Bir Al Ater area, in the Tebessa region.
Police kill two Islamist militants and seize a large cache of weapons.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: An Italian tourist is abducted by a group of men with automatic weapons, while three others she was traveling with were freed. There is no immediate claim of responsibility, however authorities believe AQLMI is involved due to their history of operations in the region.
Police kill three Islamist militants in an ambush and raid their hideout.

In recent weeks, a number of youth protests were recorded in Sour El Ghozlane, where hundreds of unemployed youth protested outside the headquarters of the daira and that of the employment agency, to denounce the lack of transparency in the treatment of job seekers records.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Algerian forces have killed a senior Islamic militant of the AQLMI linked with two attacks in 2007 in the capital Algiers that left dozens dead. He was known under the aliases of Kamel Bourihane and Abou Hafs.

column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: A commander with the National Peoples Army [ANP] was killed on 5 February during a skirmish that occurred between an ANP patrol and a militant group on the heights of Thenia 15 kilometres to the east of Boumerdes.
Algerian forces kill two Islamist militants during a skirmish with soldiers.

Algerian police beat up ""many of the 100 youths"" who gathered ""peacefully"" in front the Labour Ministry in Algiers to demand jobs on 6 February. One of the protesters tried to set himself on fire ""to express his distress"".

column7: CNDDC: National Committee for the Defence of the Rights of the Unemployed
column17: Responding to the call of the National Advocacy Committee of unemployed, twenty young unemployed people protested on 6 February outside the headquarters of the Ministry Labour, Employment and social Security, demanding their right to decent work.
An attack targeted a Gendarmerie convoy escorting workers from an Italian company in Zemmouri, injuring two gendarmes.

A total of five people were killed when a bomb hit a vehicle. The blast occurred on 8 March when a vehicle passed the area of Messaad in Djelfa Province, 200 km south of Algiers, killing five passengers. It struck a group of bird hunters travelling in an all-terrain vehicle.

A total of five people were killed when a bomb hit a vehicle. The blast occurred on 8 March when a vehicle passed the area of Messaad in Djelfa Province, 200 km south of Algiers, killing five passengers. It struck a group of bird hunters travelling in an all-terrain vehicle.

On 9 February, hundreds of students from the Superior School of Computer Science (ESI), the National School of Public Works, of Epau and the National Agronomy School gathered in front of the headquarters of the Ministry of higher Education to protest a presidential decree No. 10-315 fixing the wage scales and salaries of civil servants pay plan.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: A gendarme was killed on 10 February in downtown Baghlia, 40 kilometres east of Boumerdes, by a Al-Qaidah in the Lands of the Islamic Maghreb, or AQIM. The victim, who worked in Algiers with the Republican Guard, had been on leave when he was targeted by two armed individuals, who fired on him at point blank range. The attack occurred when the gendarme was in civilian clothing and was getting ready to get into his vehicle after having done errands at the cities market.
Security forces kill two militants of the GIA organization in the Tafrnet region, in the municipality of Tagouraya, 90 kilometres south of the city of Sidi Bel Abbes on 11 February.

column9: RCD: Rally for Culture and Democracy Party
column17: Police officers broke up a gathering of people outside the Algiers offices for the opposition Rally for Culture and Democracy (RCD), as they celebrated Mubaraks downfall. Police charged the demonstrators and arrested 10 people, said RCD leader Said Sadi, adding that several protestors had to be treated in hospital.

Scuffles broke out and security forces arrested 400 demonstrators early in the day as around 2,000 of pro-democracy protesters assembled for a banned march calling for regime change in Algeria. The protesters were reportedly inspired by the effectiveness of the tactic in Egypt. Of the arrested was the leader (Ali Benhadj) of a banned political party, the FIS. The demonstrators chanted 'Bouteflika out!'
On 12 February, a group of youths clashed with riot police in Amizour Town, 50 km to the east of Akbou. The clashes lasted until midnight.
In Akbou, a few protesters set fire to tires, up to the Hafsa school on 12 February. Police arrested a number of young people protesting in front of the court.

column7: CNCD: National Coordination for Change and Democracy
column17: Thousands gathered in the Algiers May 1st Square to protest against President Abdelaziz Bouteflika. Police were able to quickly disperse the crowd. The CNCD, an umbrella group of opposition parties, civil society movements and unofficial unions announced the march in Algiers.
Dozens of youths took to streets in Algerias capital of Algiers on 12 February, chanting pro- president slogans in response to the ongoing anti-government march called by opposition parties.

In Sidi Aich, a group of youths burned tires at an intersection, located in downtown, disrupting vehicular traffic, before traveling to the headquarters of the Security daira for stoning. Police managed to disperse them. The protesters chanted slogans in support of the National Coordination for Change and Democracy (CNCD). They called for the toppling of the regime and for guaranteeing public freedoms.

Scuffles broke out and security forces arrested 400 demonstrators early in the day as around 2,000 of pro-democracy protesters assembled for a banned march calling for regime change in Algeria. The protesters were reportedly inspired by the effectiveness of the tactic in Egypt. Of the arrested was the leader (Ali Benhadj) of a banned political party, the FIS. The demonstrators chanted 'Bouteflika out!'

On 12 February in Oran a demonstration that had been banned by the authorities went ahead, with between 400 and 500 protestors rallying in a central square by 11 am. A dozen arrests were reportedly made.

column9: CNCD: National Coordination for Change and Democracy
column17: Young people, thugs according to witnesses, fired up, and shouting pro-Bouteflika slogans, assaulted protesters in Algiers.
A third militant was killed in the Tafrnet region, in the municipality of Tagouraya, 90 kilometres south of the city of Sidi Bel Abbes on 12 February.

Following the arrest of a journalist during a demonstration in Annaba, a guild of journalists gathered outside the province to demand his immediate release. For nearly thirty minutes, the journalists of the wilaya of Annaba observed a sit-in outside the headquarters to protest against this act.

Nearly a hundred citizens, especially young people, gathered to express their adherence to the movement initiated by the National Coordination for Change and Democracy (CNCD). Police deployment was present on 12 February.
In Bejaia, an attempt to rally a group of protesters in height of the popular district of Ihaddadene was cut short. Demonstrators blocked roads with stones and other objects.

A group of young people from the cities ""Cnep"" and ""240 homes"" in Tizi Ouzou tried on 12 February to block traffic near the bus station, with various objects. The rapid intervention of the police reopened the road to traffic.

Hundreds of youths clashed with riot police in Akbou City [in Kabylies Bejaia Province, some 180 km to the east of Algiers] on 13 February during which more than 30 people - most of them protesters - were wounded. The clashes escalated when a large number of youths tried to storm the police station in an attempt to destroy it. This lead the security forces to confront them by resorting to extensive use of tear gas canisters.
Rioters protesting unemployment opportunities throw stones at police trying to quell them. Four police officers hurt.
Protests erupted in the city Didouche-Mourad, witnessing the destruction of street furniture, degradation of private vehicles and other scenes of degradation.

column7: CNCD: National Coordination for Change and Democracy
column17: Members of the CNCD clash with police when they attempt to protest the overthrow of the national government.
Rioters protest in front of a local courthouse for unknown reasons, many clash with police who try to disperse them.
Around 500 jobless youths protested on 16 February near the gas fields of Hassi Messaoud.

column7: Military Forces of Algeria (1999-) Municipal Guard
column17: A group of communal guards citizens armed by the state to fight the two-decades-long Islamist insurgency joined the protest on 16 February in front of the governors office in Medea, around 60 miles (100 kilometers) south of Algiers to demand a variety of social benefits.

A score of young pro-regime supporters protested in Algiers on 19 February holding pictures of President Abdelaziz Bouteflika and shouting: ""Police officers, let us pick a fight with them!"" [referring to anti-government protesters].

column7: CNCD: National Coordination for Change and Democracy
column17: 2,000 anti-regime protesters, organized by the CNCD, fill the May 1st Square where they are met by riot police. Many of the protesters barricaded streets. The police eventually push back and disperse the protesters without reported violence.
A demonstrating lawmaker was hospitalized after suffering a head wound when he fell after police kicked and hit him, colleagues said.

column7: CNCD: National Coordination for Change and Democracy
column17: Dozens of people held a rally in a movie theatre in Oran (432 km west of Algiers) on 19 February called for by the National Coordination for Democracy and Change (CNDC).

At least one person was injured Monday when protesting students in the capital Algiers clashed with police who tried to stop their demonstration at the ministry for higher education. A student was injured when security forces blocked protestors from reaching the ministry. Students were calling for the abrogation of a presidential decree which makes it difficult to obtain a master degree.

In northeastern Annaba, seven unemployed people staged a protest on the roof of the administration building in which they mutilated themselves. One lost consciousness after slashing his torso and was taken to hospital.
A group of men, armed with AK-47s, are shot and killed by members of the military.

column7: CNCD: National Coordination for Change and Democracy; Students (Algeria)
column17: A lawmaker of the Rally for Culture and Democracy Party is injured and six students are arrested when they are confronted by police as they protest the regime. The remaining protesters were dispersed.

column7: RCD: Rally for Culture and Democracy Party; Students (Algeria)
column17: A lawmaker of the Rally for Culture and Democracy Party is injured and six students are arrested when they are confronted by police as they protest the regime.
Members of the RCD attempt to stage another protest against the regime before it is quickly dispersed by the police.

column7: RCD: Rally for Culture and Democracy Party
column17: Members of the RCD attempt to stage another protest against the regime before it is quickly dispersed by the police.

column7: CNCD: National Coordination for Change and Democracy
column17: The RCD, an opposition umbrella group holds a rally along with a socialist group for government reforms, including higher wages and better housing. Nearly 3,000 attended.
Protests in Tindouf to denounce polisarios repressive, corrupted policy were met with violence by polisario on 5 March in front of the headquarters of the polisario Front in Rabouni.

column7: CNCD: National Coordination for Change and Democracy
column17: Members of the CNCD attempt to protest before they are surrounded and dispersed by pro-regime supporters and the police.

column7: CNCD: National Coordination for Change and Democracy
column17: Members of the CNCD attempt to protest before they are surrounded and dispersed by pro-regime supporters and the police. Police and counter-demonstrators chased them and roughed up them up, threatening to ""lynch"" supporters of CNCD.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Military members kill AQIM leader Bouher Mourad El Mekni Abou Tourab, in Tala Oubrid, in Bordj Menial. Several AK-47s were recovered following the operation.

column7: Military Forces of Algeria (1999-) Municipal Guard
column17: Thousands of Algerian anti- terrorism municipal guards demonstrated in the capital demanding higher wages.
A roadside explosive detonated along side a vehicle killing five people.

column7: CNCD: National Coordination for Change and Democracy
column17: Anti-riot police put down an anti Bouteflika protest before it is able to begin.

column9: UGEL: General Union of Free Students; Students (Algeria)
column17: At the university in the center of Bouira, students of the local coordination of independent students and those of UGEL clashed resulting in the injury of six students, some evacuated to the hospital in the city.

Forces of the National Peoples Army [ANP], which were on operation in the maquis of Sidi Ali Bounab west of Tizi Ouzou, killed a militant in the village of Ichakalen, in the municipality of Tadmait. A resident was slightly wounded following the explosion of two rockets which fell close to homes in the village of Abla, located three kilometres west of Tadmait during the shelling of the surrounding maquis by the army.
On 14 March, a group of young unemployed blocked the road up to the village of Wadi Ziad, cutting the main route linking Annaba to Berrahal, Skikda and Constantine.

On 14 March, unemployed youth demanding work blocked the road to the town of El Kous, on the road to El Tarf. The road was blocked by miscellaneous objects and burning tires, closing the road to traffic.
A group of youths clash with police when they begin throwing rocks and petrol bombs at them in protest of the condition of their dilapidated homes. There is no report of injury or death.
A group of youths clash with police when they begin throwing rocks and petrol bombs at them in protest of the condition of their dilapidated homes. There is no report of injury or death.

An unknown group kills two with a roadside bomb. The group set up an ambush on a road linking Zemouri town and Legata town in Boumerdes district, before opening fire on a vehicle and killed two people on board. An elected official from the Workers Party [PT] was one of those killed.
500 officers of the Civil Defence (firefighters) representing all provinces of the country held a sit-in outside the headquarters of the General Union of Algerian Workers (UGTA) in Algiers.
Thousands stage pro-democracy march in Tizi Ouzou.

column9: CNCD: National Coordination for Change and Democracy
column17: A force of several hundred police officers was deployed to the center of Algiers on the morning of March 19, 2011, to drive back several dozen demonstrators. A small number of protesters made it through the barricades. Youths protested outside the main post office and at nearby May 1 Square, National Coordination for Change and Democracy (CNDC) and RCD members protested.
Rioters, protesting the demolition of houses, clashes with police, leaving 21 police injured, one rioter injured and the death of seven month old baby girl, asphyxiated by the polices tear gas.

Rioters, protesting the demolition of houses in Climate de France in Oued Koriche district of Algiers, clashed with police, leaving 21 police injured, one rioter injured and the death of seven month old baby girl dead, asphyxiated by the polices tear gas.
Rioters, protesting the demolition of houses, clashes with police, leaving 21 police injured, one rioter injured and the death of seven month old baby girl dead, asphyxiated by the polices tear gas.
Opposition activists clashed with police in Oued Keriche, Algiers. Around 20 people have been wounded, among them police officers.
A militant was eliminated during the evening of Friday, 25 March, in the community of Tadmait, 20 km west of Tizi Ouzou

column7: CNCD: National Coordination for Change and Democracy
column17: Police again scuffle with reform protesters.

column7: CNCD: National Coordination for Change and Democracy
column17: Police again scuffle with reform protesters.A few dozen demonstrators turned out on May 1 Square in central Algiers with the intention of marching to Martyrs Square some three kilometres (two miles) away.
Journalists held a sit-in on March 27 to protest for an increase in salaries.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Military forces kill a militant who crossed the border from Libya armed with AK-47s. The militant was reported to be an aide to the ""amir"" from the Tarek-Ibn-Ziad brigade. He slipped into Algerian territory from the Libyan border. He had been coming, from the Libyan city of Ghadamis, 12 km from the Algerian city of Deb Deb, before being spotted by soldiers who successfully neutralized him after a car chase and a skirmish.
A few dozen representatives of the families victims of ""terrorism"" converged towards the government palace on 3 April to protest against their living conditions.

column7: Military Forces of Algeria (1999-) Municipal Guard
column17: Thousands of Algerian municipal guards protest in Algiers demanding better working conditions. Hundreds of municipal security guards (village police) rallied on 3 April in Algerian capital of Algiers, protesting the governments non commitment towards their professional and social claims.
On April 4, journalists held a protest sit-in at the National Radio (Radio Algerienne) building over pay and conditions.

column7: Military Forces of Algeria (1999-) Municipal Guard
column17: Members of the auxiliary security militia kept up a sit-in at Martyrs Square in the capital on 6 April. They demandeds increases in pay and pensions, integration into the regular security forces and the rehiring of colleagues who have been laid off.
Doctors begin sit-in in front of presidential palace in Algiers.
Thousands of anti-regime students marched at the Presidential Palace to protest the ""devaluation"" of their qualification. Police dispersed the protestors by force, leaving 30 people injured.

Hundreds of students staged a sit-in outside the ministry on 13 April in Ben Aknoun, in the western part of Algiers. A group of young men carrying knives threatened students in a sit-in outside the Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research in Algerian capital city [Algiers] after the security forces prevented pharmaceutical students from staging a sit-in outside the presidential palace and presidents office. No reports of injuries.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: An AQIM attack on a military guard post kills 17 soldiers and one of their assailants. AQIM claimed control of the army barracks. Following the attack, an operation killed six militants, among them the amir from the Yakouren seriat of the ex-Salafi Group for Call and Combat [GSPC], which has become Al-Qaida in the Lands of the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM).
The Algerian army kills six militants in Tizi Ouzou.
Five soldiers and two militants were killed in clashes between government forces and armed Islamists in Ammal area, 30 km south of Boumerdes on 17 April.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Militants kill a gendarme during a bomb attack.
The Algerian armed forces eliminated on 18 April two militants and arrested another, after a fireclash in Djerrah, in Boumerdes province, 60 km east of capital Algiers.
A militant was killed in Ain Defla province, 150 km west of Algiers, following a combing operation conducted by the army in Tareq Ibn Ziad, while a communal guard was wounded in this operation.
Teachers begin sit-in in Algerian capital.
Four Libyan militants are killed, two arrested in a clash with soldiers.
Three Libyan militants are killed in a clash with soldiers.
Algerian police disperse protestors from Amazigh Arouch Movement, three injured. No location indicated.

Army units, backed by helicopters and National Gendarmerie forces, eliminated three militants, two Algerians and a Mauritanian in Illizi, who were about to transport a load of weapons from Libya. A reliable security source said that the first clash had taken place in Ain Zouiti area, 200 km from the Algerian-Libyan borders.

column9: CNCD: National Coordination for Change and Democracy
column17: Algerian police beat hundreds of pro-reform activists outside parliament and prevented another anti-government rally on 23 April. Hundreds of teachers gathered in central Algiers but police beat them back and swooped down on marchers gathered about two kilometres away in another protest called by the National Coordination for Democracy and Change (CNDC). No one seriously injured.
On the evening of Sunday, 24 April, four militants were killed by soldiers in the Khenafou mountains located on the border between Bejaia and Bordj Bou Arreridj.

A group of armed men tried to attack Palestinian ambassador to Algeria Hocine Abdelkhalek. It was described as an ""assassination attempt."" Three men armed with knives and sticks entered the envoys office in the Algerian capital on 25 April and a fight erupted.

Between 150 and 200 people gathered on 26 April on the square El Kahina (former Cathedral) to gather in memory of professor and activist of Human Rights, Ahmed Kerroumi, and demand that the truth be made quickly on conditions of his death between Tuesday 19 and Saturday, April 23rd.

Scores of Syrian and Algerian citizens gather in front of the Syrian Embassy in Algiers to condemn what they called killings carried out by the Syrian security forces against unarmed citizens. They called for the departure of the Syrian president.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: A bomb kills two soldiers as they were traveling in their vehicle.
Five security guards killed and four wounded when they are attacked by unknown persons.
Three police are killed in an ambush.
Students protested against ""depreciation"" of university degrees in Algiers.
Unemployed group holds Labour Day march in Algiers, protestors released after brief detention.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: A militant is killed by security forces.
Security forces clash with student anti-regime protesters in front of the capital building. More than 20 hurt.
Algerian journalists gathered in the capital Algiers on World Press Freedom Day Tuesday, pressing for better salaries and training.
Security forces staged a violent clampdown on a demonstration by hundreds of striking medical specialists in the Algerian capital on Wednesday, in which 10 people were injured, a doctors group said.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: A reporter is shot dead by militants.

On May 6, demonstrators laid waste to several hotels in the Tichi area, demanding their closure for ""offending the moral standards of the region"". The protesters called themselves the May 6 Movement and said their aim was to put an end to bad social trends.
Five soldiers are killed and another five wounded in a militants bomb explosion.

Nearly a hundred citizens living in the popular area of ""Djabanet Lihoud"" in Annaba protested to demand to be placed on the list of beneficiaries of housing recently released. A taxi driver was attacked by young protesters.
Hundreds of students gather at Algiers central university, Algeria; attempt to form demonstration but prevented by security forces.
Police block a protest by striking doctors and health care students who were demanding new government rules in their profession,

A journalist with Algerias national radio service was seriously injured in an attack by two armed men who broke into his office at the Mouloud Mammeri cultural centre in Tizi Ouzou as security officers looked on, on 11 May. Simultaneously, an 18-year-old man kidnapped by an armed group on May 11.
The Director of EMC Taheyat-Ahmed is severely assaulted by unknown individuals.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Seven soldiers and three militants are killed, one missing, when a military barracks came under assault.
On May 14, a 71-year-old man was abducted from his home in Mechtras.
Two militants and a soldier are killed in a skirmish.
Security forces kill two ""Islamist Militants"" in a gunfight.
One soldier is killed, two wounded during a gunfight with militants in the bush of Berkmouch, near Ath (Beni) Yenni, 40 kilometres southeast of Tizi Ouzou.

Hundreds of teachers marched on 17 May in Kherrata to denounce the climate of insecurity and violence prevailing in the vicinity of schools. This action comes days after the assault of the Director of EMC Taheyat-Ahmed of the same locality by a gang of ""thugs"".

column7: CNEC: National Coordination of Children of Chouhada
column17: On 21 May, the president of the CNEC: National Coordination of Children of Chouhada (Martyrs) (CNEC) held a rally in Algiers against corruption and embezzlement of public funds.

column6: Military Forces of Algeria (1999-) Border Guard
column7: Military Forces of Algeria (1999-) Special Forces
column17: Algerian army forces killed three militants and arrested another in an ambush at the borders with Niger. Joint security forces of border guards and army special forces conducted the operation, which occurred near Oued Tafssit on the desert border between Algeria and Niger.

A vehicle belonging to the coast guard in Azeffoun escaped a bomb attack on Monday, 23 May. The bomb exploded as a vehicle from the navy went past which was leaving the surveillance post located in Ait Maalem, not far from Azeffoun, 60 kilometres northeast of Tizi Ouzou. No injuries reported.
Two soldiers are killed by a roadside bomb triggered by remote control. 6
Local police foil a suicide bomber from entering their police station. The unknown individual was shot and killed.
Four police are killed by a roadside bomb as they passed the Chender area between Bordj-Menaiel and Naciria in Boumerdes Province, some 70 km east of the capital city of Algiers.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: A group of armed men kill three soldiers. They are believed to be part of the AQIM network.

In Oran, medical residents observed a national sit-in inside the University Hospital of Oran on 8 June. The striking doctors still claim the abolition of compulsory civil service, and denounced the abuses and excesses that have been committed by security forces against medical residents.

Hundreds of jobless youth in the province of Ouargla in south-east Algeria were subject to force by anti-riot police that used force to break up a sit-in they staged in front of the local governments headquarters. Anti-riot police along with the national gendarmerie used ""force"" in trying to disperse youth who staged a sit-in to demand jobs.
Syrians protest in Algiers in support of uprising on 11 June.

A soldier is killed, two are wounded when a buried bomb is detonated remotely on the road in the village of Taboudoucht, in the municipality of Aghribs, 30 or so kilometres from the city of Tizi Ouzou.

column6: Military Forces of Algeria (1999-) Municipal Guard
column17: A municipal guard from the detachment in the municipality of Timezrit (50 kilometres east of Boumerdes) was wounded on 15 June in a bomb attack perpetrated on the road leading towards Naciria. The bomb had been planted by the side of the road, in the spot known as Tizouighine, before being triggered remotely. One of them was hit slightly by the debris from the explosive device.

column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: The treasurer from the seriat from the ex-Salafi Group for Call and Combat [GSPC; the group now known as Al-Qaidah in the Lands of the Islamic Maghreb, AQLIM] was killed on 16 June by the security forces in Bouaidal, on the heights of Si Mustapha 15 kilometres east of Boumerdes.
A police officer is wounded by a roadside bomb blast.
Police in Algiers disperse pro-democracy protestors.
Ex-army officers rally in Algiers to demand compensation for being called up during civil unrest in 1990s.
A soldier and two militia members are wounded when a homemade bomb is detonated.
Soldiers mistakenly shoot and kill a father of five, thinking he was a suicide bomber.
A military convoy was attacked with a bomb, six soldiers wounded, one soldier and one civilian killed.
A military convoy is attacked, six soldiers wounded, one soldier and one civilian killed.
A spontaneous gathering of several dozen people was held outside the headquarters of the PCA and the crowd chanted against the killing of a man by security forces.

Another general strike, supported by a popular march was scheduled to be held in Azazga to denounce the murder of a man and demanding an ""independent investigation"" into the circumstances of the act and at the call for the Coordination of village committees Azazga and the crisis following the case.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Two soldiers are killed and five injured when a roadside explosion is detonated at Legata, 15 kilometres (10 miles) east of the town of Boumerdes. One civilians was also injured in the blast.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Security forces kill two armed militants, believed to be of the AQIM organization.
Algerian lawyers hold a march in protest at changes to a law that they say will undermine the independence of the judiciairy.

15 Chinese workers blocked a road because their employer had decided to send them back home. The workers, who were building a jail in Abadla in Bechar province, had refused to return to China after their Algerian work permits expired.
Lawyers march in Algiers against draft law on legal profession.

A roadside bomb killed an Algerian soldier and wounded two others, including a senior officer, east of the capital in the second such incident in less than a week. The improvised explosive device buried in the ground was triggered as a patrol passed on its way back to camp in the Boumerdes region, 40 kilometres (25 miles) from Algiers, on 1 July.
On Friday 1 July 2011, four policemen were injured in a suicide bomb attack at the entrance to the city of Azeffoun. The same source conflictingly reported that the bomb was remotely detonated.

A police officer is killed and another wounded during a clash with militants. One of the assailants was gunned down by police who lost one man while another officer was rushed to hospital with serious injuries.

column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Two soldiers were killed in the town of Legata, near Zemmouri. The attacks are the work of armed groups of Al Qaeda in Islamic Maghreb (AQIM), who are still active in Eastern regions including the Kabylie country.
Two protesters are hurt by polices rubber bullets and tear gas when they demonstrate against a building project that would replace a nearby park.

Ten people were wounded in Algiers when police used teargas and rubber bullets to break up a protest by residents opposed to the construction of a car park. A few dozens residents gathered to protest against the building project, which would destroy a nearby park and negatively affect quality of life in their neighbourhood of Hydra. Police fired teargas grenades and rubber bullets to which the protestors responded by throwing stones, in clashes that left 10 people wounded
A member of a militia is assassinated by an armed group when he is shot not far from his home.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Soldiers go on a search & destroy mission for AQIM. Two killed, seven arrested.
In Naciria, a few kilometers from Baghlia, a soldier was killed and two others injured following the explosion of a bomb buried underground.
On Wednesday a bomb attack at a military post near Baghlia killed two soldiers and wounded six more. Troops were subsequently involved in a fierce gun battle with insurgents there.
Security forces shoot and kill two gunmen close to the border of Tunisia.

column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Elements of the peoples national army foiled an infiltration attempt by AQIM militants from Niger to Libya. A military force destroyed on [16-17 July] two 4x4 cars, killing the passengers who were inside after a clash in the region of Tissidrine in the so-called tri-border area between Algeria, Niger and Libya. The army succeeded in retrieving documents belonging to Al-Qaidah [Organization] in the Land of the Islamic Maghreb [AQLIM].

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Two are killed and fifteen wounded in a pair of suicide attacks from AQIM, including a car bomb near a police station.
Eleven soldiers are wounded, two of the seriously, when a roadside bomb is detonated west of the city of Bouira.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Army kills three armed militants including a top member of an Al-Qaeda regional offshoot.
A suicide bomber blows himself up to avoid arrest. There were no other injuries or causalities.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: The son of former FIS leader Ali Belhadj, Abdelkahar Belhadj, now of AQIM, was killed by security forces while he was travelling with a group of armed men en route to Algiers.
Security forces confiscate 218 pieces of western weaponry smuggled out of Libya over the course of a month. The weapons were presumably intended for Libyan rebels.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Two soldiers are killed and several others injured when AQIM detonates an explosive alongside their convoy.
Joint security forces killed a militant and injured another in the village of Dar Zitoune in Bourdj Bou Arreridj province, 250 km east of Algiers.
Security forces seize several handmade bombs, explosive belts and other ammunition in a warehouse raid.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Four killed in an internal clash among al-Qaeda branches.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Thirty-three people, including eleven police are injured when a suicide attacker targeted a police station in a heavily trafficked downtown area. AQIM claimed responsibility.

column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: A bomb struck a military convoy on 16 August in the Boumerdes region, 50 kilometres east of the capital, killing a soldier and wounding five others. The attack was attributed to AQIM.
Defusal: Security forces foil a bomb attack that was planted under a car in a garage.

Clashes were reported on 17 August with police services in Beni Douala. Combing operations were conducted at Eth Eissa and Beni Douala woods in Tizi Ouzou by the army killing of four militant members of the ""Kechkech"" group.
On 17 August, a bomb explosion in Si Mustapha [Boumerdes Province, 56 km east of Algiers] caused the death of one person and the injury of five persons.
The driver for a local police chief, a road transport operator and a hospital worker are killed when they are ambushed by an unnamed terror group.

column9: Military Forces of Algeria (1999-) Municipal Guard
column17: A militant group killed the chief of municipal guards (village police) in the locality of Zemouri in Boumerdes, 60 km east of Algiers. Three armed men launched a surprise attack at the victims house and shot him dead.

A group of militants, who attempted to abduct a young man on 18 August in the village of El Bir village, Mouaatka in northern province of Tizi Ouzou, attacked and killed three villagers who tried to rescue the kidnapped man.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: A policeman died on 17 August of his wounds after AQIM militants opened fire on a vehicle near the town of Tizi Ouzou, 110 kilometres (70 miles) east of the capital Algiers. The driver was also killed in the shooting blamed on militants from Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM).
On Thursday [18 August] in Azeffoun, an army captain was injured following the explosion of a hand- made bomb.

Algerian forces killed two militants suspected of involvement in an attack that left three people dead in the region of Kabylie. Two of the suspected attackers were caught by security on Friday at a checkpoint near Maatkas, a town located 25 kilometres (15 miles) south of the regional capital Tizi Ouzou.
A member of a militant group was eliminated on 20 August near Souk El Tnine in the region of Maatkas.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Security forces kill two militants, recover several AK-47 rifles.
Security services killed three militants in an ambush set in the night of 22 - 23 August in the locality of Bouadil, Municipality of Ammal, Boumerdes province, 60 km east of Algiers the capital.
Two police are targeted and killed by an armed group, a civilian is wounded.
Two police are targeted and killed by an armed group, a civilian is wounded.

An army and gendarmerie joint force eliminated five militants believed to be members of a Salafia Jihadia group that was fighting in Libya, in the region of Gholana, 320 km south east of the Debdeb municipality from 25-26 August. The infiltrators refused to surrender and fired back with rockets, injuring a soldier. The clash ended with the killing of four of the armed men, and the injury of their fifth associate, who died a few hours later.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: 18 people were killed, 26 others wounded when a suicide attacker targets a military academy. AQIM claims responsibility for the attack. The two bombers also died
A soldier is killed and a second wounded in a bomb blast delivered remotely, under an automobile.
Youths riot over the demolition of housing structures, throwing rocks and glass bottles, eventually getting into a long battle with police forces. Several injuries.
Youths riot over the demolition of housing structures, throwing rocks and glass bottles, eventually getting into a long battle with police forces. Several injuries.

Security forces and a militant group exchange fire. No report of death or injury. Soldiers stationed in the Beni Douala region skirmished with a major militant group near the village of Taguemount Oukerouche, in the Beni Douala region, 20 or so kilometres south of the city of Tizi Ouzou

column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: The military conducted intensive bombardments of Mounts Tamgout and Echaara, in Yakourene, in the dense forest located between the Ain El Hammam and Mekla regions, and in the Akfadou massif as well. During the entire day on Tuesday, combat helicopters pounded the far east of the wilaya of Tizi Ouzou and the west of the wilaya of Bejaia, especially the Adekar region

column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: The military conducted intensive bombardments of Mounts Tamgout and Echaara, in Yakourene, in the dense forest located between the Ain El Hammam and Mekla regions, and in the Akfadou massif as well. During the entire day on Tuesday, combat helicopters pounded the far east of the wilaya of Tizi Ouzou and the west of the wilaya of Bejaia, especially the Adekar region

column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: The military conducted intensive bombardments of Mounts Tamgout and Echaara, in Yakourene, in the dense forest located between the Ain El Hammam and Mekla regions, and in the Akfadou massif as well. During the entire day on Tuesday, combat helicopters pounded the far east of the wilaya of Tizi Ouzou and the west of the wilaya of Bejaia, especially the Adekar region

column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: The military conducted intensive bombardments of Mounts Tamgout and Echaara, in Yakourene, in the dense forest located between the Ain El Hammam and Mekla regions, and in the Akfadou massif as well. During the entire day on Tuesday, combat helicopters pounded the far east of the wilaya of Tizi Ouzou and the west of the wilaya of Bejaia, especially the Adekar region

A mob of around 100 youths tried to set fire to two private dailies printing plant in Algiers. The mob, armed with molotov cocktails, tried to storm the printing plants of the French-language El Watan and the Arabic-language El Khabar on 14 September.
A small village hold a protest demanding members of the military leave.
Gunmen wound two civilians when they are ambushed.

An Algerian military force on 21 September confronted an attempted infiltration by a group of militants on board of at least four four-wheel-drive vehicles and forced them to return to where they came from within Tunisian territory. A security source said that an hour-long battle between a military force and the gunmen resulted in the destruction of a vehicle in Beldjnah area in the southernmost part of Ouedi Souf Province.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Security forces kill a ""key"" AQIM member. The armed forces set an ambush targeting an armed group in the woods of Sidi Ali Bounab in Tizi Ouzou province.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: An unknown individual fired an RPG into an airport, but failed to make any damage or cause injury. The attack was apparently aimed at a military helicopter parked on the tarmac. Troops and police responded with machine-gun fire and launched searches in the neighbouring town of Emir Abdelkader.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: A militant was killed on Saturday [24 September] at about 2200 hours [local time] by the forces of the National Peoples Army [ANP] near Chouicha, in the municipality of Legata, 25 kilometres east of Boumerdes [some 70 km to the east of Algiers].

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: A member of the military kills a member of AQIM.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: A suspected fighter was killed on 26 September as he attempted to flee from an area surrounded by Algerian forces.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: The military kills four members of AQIM after a prolonged chase.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: On 28 September, pursuing their advance into the dense Chouicha forest, near Zemmouri, in the wilaya of Boumerdes, the security forces killed three AQIM militants.

A group of young Sahrawis staged a sit-in in front of the headquarters of the High Commissioner for Refugees in the vicinity of Tindouf, southwestern Algeria, to protest against abuses perpetrated in the camps.

Two soldiers sustained heavy injuries after a remote bomb attack on a Peoples National Army truck in Tissemsilt. The soldiers were taken to Ain el Naadja Hospital in the capital. The patrol was on a routine mission transporting provisions in Mala region.

column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Algerian army forces killed eight militants pertaining to al-Qaida in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) in Bordj Houine, a desert area on the border with Niger and Libya and seized some arms smuggled from Libya on 2 October.
Algerian police on 5 October briefly detained 17 people as they prepared to hold a rally commemorating bloody pro-democracy protests of 1988 in Algiers.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Two Algerian Marines are killed when they drove over an explosive believed to placed there by AQIM.
Four militants are killed by security forces.

column7: CNDDC: National Committee for the Defence of the Rights of the Unemployed
column17: Police arrest 25 members of the CNDDC, an unemployment rights group, as they protest for their cause.

column6: CNCD: National Coordination for Change and Democracy
column17: Arrests: Police arrest 25 members of the CNDCC, an unemployment rights group, as they protest for their cause.
A bomb, targeted at military forces, instead injures four civilians. It is unclear who detonated the device.

On 11 October, a homemade bomb exploded at 0930 hours as a military convoy went past not far from the new Bouhinoun bus station, located less than one kilometre south of the city of Tizi Ouzou, without causing either injuries or material damages.

column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: An AQIM militant was killed on Sunday 16 October near the village of Ait Idir, in the municipality of Beni Douala, 15 or so kilometres south of the city of Tizi Ouzou by members of the ANP.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: A bomb, believed to be planted by the AQIM explodes, kills a woman and injures others, including a child.

Demonstrations were staged in the city of Bejaia in recent days to protest against delays in the construction of social housing and to call for better access to water and electricity. Some rioting took place and city dwellers blocked the highway and railway to demand a reduction in fares. The police are dealing with demonstrators in Bejaia itself while gendarmes patrol rural areas around the city.
Four gendarmes are injured in a roadside style bomb blast as they were returning to this barracks in an adjacent town.

column7: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Three aid workers, two Spaniards and one Italian are kidnapped from the Saharawi refugee camps where they worked by suspected AQIM militants aided by Polisario Front members. One of the hostages and a local guard were injured in the attack.

column7: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Military forces shoot and kill four gunmen believed to be involved with recent abduction of three European aid workers.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Members of the military kill four members of AQIM in an unknown location.
A young man was killed during violent clashes on 2 November between some residents of the Sidi Saadi neighbourhood in Beni Messous on the heights of Algiers over rehousing policy.

A repentant militant was killed on the night between Wednesday and Thursday [2 to 3 November] by a group of gunmen near the town of Haj Ahmed in the municipality of Zemmouri, 12 km east of Boumerdes Province.

On 10 November, a militant group attempted to storm a National Gendarmerie barracks in the town of Tazmalt [Bejaia Province]. The militant opened fire towards the main gate and then fled when the National Gendarmerie personnel retaliated.

column9: Military Forces of Algeria (1999-) Border Guards
column17: A military unit captured five gunmen near the border with Libya and recovered 70 pieces of various kinds of weaponry smuggled out of Libya and a quantity of ammunition on board of a four-wheel-drive truck stolen from the Libyan army. A military unit backed by Border Guard Forces killed two gunmen, who were believed to be Malian nationals, and captured five others. The association of the gunmen is not known; however, armed groups like AQIM is known to traffic weapons from Libya to Mali.
Students rally outside Syrias embassy in Algiers in support of uprising.

Protesters in Sour El Ghozlan on Thursday [1 December] closed different neighbourhoods, streets, all four of the towns entrances, in addition to all of the provincial and national roads passing through the region using rubber wheels and tree trunks to protest poor conditions of the town. Security forces and the town chief intervened in a move to try and placate the anger of the protestors.

A gendarme was wounded in a bomb attack on 16 December near the community of Ammal, 25 kilometres south of Boumerdes. The device had been planted by the side of National Road [RN] 5, in the spot known as El Kalaa. It was triggered remotely as a convoy from the National Gendarmerie drove past that had been getting ready to return to the camp set up between Ammal and Beni Amrane.

Workers of Sarl SGS Sagiss (security company) in Rouiba started a strike on 20 December. They are holding daily sit-ins outside the entrance to the SNVI. Their protest has been in order to demand a wage increase, the establishment of a local union affiliated to the UGTA and the departure the director of the public entity, created by five public companies including SNVI, ANABIB, Difrachim, BGA and GTP.

Several provinces of the country witnessed protests linked to unemployment, urban planning, lack of gas and water, and especially to housing problem. In the province of Tipasa, west of Algiers, citizens of Halloula-Essahilia village last Thursday took to the streets and blocked National Road 67 to protest against the cancellation of the scheduled visit of the governor of Tipasa, during which they hoped to present their grievances to the first responsible of the province. They used burning tires and other objects to denounce the lack of drinking water in homes pipes for five days, the fall of a child in a sewer and to claim social order.

Several provinces of the country witnessed protests linked to unemployment, urban planning, lack of gas and water, and especially to housing problem. Residents of Kerrouh and Chebilia neighbourhood, located in the town of Hammam-Dalaa, 30 km from the province of Msila, closed the National Road 6 linking the centre of the municipality to provinces city centre. Protesters demand urban planning and challenge the relocation operation launched recently.

Algerian authorities arrest a group of arms dealers from Libya near the border. The joint forces, supported by assault helicopters, pursued a militant group in a rocky desert area, southwest of Tegasist, used by smugglers to sneak into Algeria from Niger. Available information indicated that the Algerian army killed two militants and it was about to launch a big military operation with a view to combing vast areas of the desert. The association of the gunmen is not known; however, armed groups like AQIM is known to traffic weapons from Libya to Mali.

Several provinces of the country witnessed protests linked to unemployment, urban planning, lack of gas and water, and especially to housing problem. The population of Bogssiaa, one of the most populous neighbourhoods of Baghlia, a municipality east of Boumerdes, Sunday have proceeded openly to the closure of CPA Banks offices to demand the restoration of wastewater system as soon as possible.

Several provinces of the country witnessed protests linked to unemployment, urban planning, lack of gas and water, and especially to housing problem. After having closed National Road 33, the town hall and the districts premises, the population of Haizer, in Bouira Province, east of Algiers, drove districts governor out. For them, he has failed in his mission, which is the development of the city in general and that of city centre, in particular. Protesters threaten to harden their movement if he took up his post. With the help of stones and tree trunks, they had closed all roads leading to Haizer. Citizens ask for taking care of their claims: rehabilitation of roads, solution to the lack of clean water, public facilities and relocation in remote areas.

Several provinces of the country witnessed protests linked to unemployment, urban planning, lack of gas and water, and especially to housing problem. Many citizens who were not allocated housing units closed the National Road 26 in the town of Hellouane, located at the western outskirts of the Ifri-Ouzellaguen District, province of Bejaia, leading to significant closures in both directions of the main road. The old highway linking the city to Ighzer-Amokrane Lazib, in the municipality of Akbou, was closed by another group of demonstrators in the same city of Hellouane. They protested against the way in which these 64 housing units were distributed by local authorities.

Several provinces of the country witnessed protests linked to unemployment, urban planning, lack of gas and water, and especially to housing problem. In Oued Athmania, south of Mila Province, [east of Algiers], the largest highway (National Road 5) for car traffic in the province was blocked Monday morning. Barricades were erected on the roadway by dozens of people. The protesters claim drinking water, rural housing and the diversion of the trucks fleet that crosses rural area daily.

Algerian troops killed a militant in the town of Beni-Melleuk, Damous in Chlef. Officers recovered weapons during the ambush operation.

The army eliminated two Libyan militants and a person with Tunisian identity paper in his possession who were about to move a consignment of weapons from Libya at the point where the Libyan, Algerian and Niger border meet. Islamist gunmen killed two people and took 41 Western hostages Wednesday in Algeria in what they said was a revenge attack on the country for opening its airspace to French warplanes hitting Islamists in Mali.

Non-violent activity: At least 20 foreign hostages escaped Thursday from Islamist militants who had taken over an Algerian natural gas complex in the Sahara desert, an Algerian security official reported.

Algerian forces on Thursday reportedly mounted a military operation against the Islamists,killing several hostages and kidnappers, according to media reports. The Algerian helicopter attacks left 35 hostages and 15 captors dead. Algerian military secured part of teh hostage site in the battle.
Four foreign hostages, including a U.S. national, were killed on Friday, the second day of the Algerian armies rescue operation at a gas facility in the southern province of Illizi.
Algerian military conduct a final assault on In Amenas facility, secure the site. 18 killed (11 militants, 7 hostages) killed in final attack.
Defusal: A mine clearance operation of the Tiguentourine gas plant, near In Amenas in the province of Illizi, attacked Wednesday by a militant group is currently underway.

An attack Sunday night in Djebahia left three Patriots Militia guards dead and seven injured. The victims reportedly prevented al-Qaedas El Farouk brigade from blowing up the Sonatrach gas pipeline between Bouira and Tizi Ouzou.
Movement of forces: Algerian army sent reinforcements to border with Mali in order to prevent the infiltration of armed combatant groups.

A group of 50 armed combatants on Wednesday [6 February] night launched an attack on a military barracks in southeastern Khenchela Province, during which heavy RPG weapons were used. The army responded with field artillery and military planes. Two armed combatants were killed and a third sustained injuries. Six soldiers were injured. AFP reported the attackers as Islamist.

Local sources suggest the attack was planned starting from the abduction of two civilians, one of whom was the driver of a truck with food supplies for the barracks and it was used to storm the barracks.

column16: Arabic Network for Human Rights Information
column17: The prison administration Algeria punished 40 prisoners in Ghardaia who have been in hunger strike for three days protesting against squalid conditions and in solidarity with the political detainee Mohamed Babah Nadjar.
Two die in skirmish with forces of the Peoples National Army [ANP] near the village of Ihnouchene, in the Aghribs region

Algerian security services killed an armed combatant on Friday night in Sidi Akkacha, 43km north of Chlef, El Moudjahid reported. The armed combatant was in a stolen vehicle earlier in the day when he killed a police officer who stopped him for an identity check.

column7: Military Forces of Algeria (1999-) Border Guards
column17: Peoples National Army, supported by units of the National Gendarmerie Forces Border Guard, killed four armed combatants in the early hours of the morning on the day before yesterday. The armed combatants belonged to Ansar Eddine Movement in Northern Mali.

A bomb explosion left an Algerian woman with serious injuries. The victim reportedly stepped on the explosive device, buried by armed combatants in an olive grove near Thenia, 15km south of Boumerdes.
ANP troops on Sunday killed two armed combatants in the Batna town of Chellala.

The National Committee for the Defence of the Rights of the Unemployed staged a stand-up protest outside the courthouse in the eastern Algerian province of Ouargla against the arrest of two youths during a peaceful demonstration to demand jobs.
Meanwhile, scores of protestors gathered outside a courthouse in Laghouat, central Algeria, to demand the release of people held during a demonstration organized by the unemployed to demand jobs.
An Algerian soldier was wounded in a bomb blast west of Bejaia on Thursday. The incident happened during an army sweep operation in the Adekar region.

Scores of people have staged protests in Algerias gas-rich region of Laghouat to demand the release of a number of unemployed youths. The demonstrators said police used tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse them, leaving some of them with breathing difficulty, according to Al-Jazeera.
