column7: CAMRA: Autonomous Medical Residents Collective; Health Workers (Algeria)
column17: On 18 April, resident medical workers protested in front of hospital CHU Dr Benbadis to call on the administration of the hospital to i.a. provide night guards.
On the week of 23 April, workers of the municipality of Oran contracted within the partial system organised a protest asking for the settlement of their professional demands.
On 24 April, Algerian police violently dispersed an illegal protest organised by the CAMRA in Algiers. Several protesters were injured by police violence.

On the week of 25 April the mayor of Bir Bouhouch in Souk Ahras was attacked by two unknown persons in his office and was injured. The two persons were sentenced to jail for several months. The motive of the attackers reportedly was a study by the mayor regarding the demands of the inhabitants of Bir Bouhouch.

Around 25 April, around 1000 workers from SIDER company protested inside the company denouncing the wage increase agreement between the administration of the enterprise and the trade union section, considering it as falling below the ambitions and expectations of the workers.

In the week fo 26 April, dozens of workers at a quarry located in Ksar Chellala protested to denounce the head of the company who tried to have them signed a document through which they would have been fired.
On the week of 27 April, lawyers organised a protest at the tribunal in Laghouat to denounce police aggression against one of their colleagues.

column7: SNSAE: National Union of Education Supervisors and Assistants; Labour Group (Algeria)
column17: On 30 April, workers from the SNSAE staged a sit-in in front of the directorate of education in Relizane to call for a revision of their salaries and regularisation of their contracts.
On 30 April, workers at Mohamed Boudiaf International Airport in Constantine protested to ask for the abolition of parking tax at the airport.

column7: CST: Workers Solidarity Committee; PST: Socialist Workers' Party
column17: On 1 May, workers in Bejaia protested in the framework of the International Workers Day following a call by the CST and the PST to denounce the harsh socio-economic conditions.

column7: SNSAE: National Union of Education Supervisors and Assistants; Labour Group (Algeria)
column17: On 4 May, workers from the SNSAE staged a protest in front of the directorate of education in Constantine to call for a revision of their salaries.
On 6 May, social housing applicants protested in Chlef to denounce being excluded from social housing beneficiaries lists.
On 7 May, social housing applicants from Merj Eddib protested in Skikda denouncing the delay in the provision of social housing units.

On 7 May, the collective for the endorsement of micro-enterprises organised a protested, driving from Ibachirene (Oued Ghir) to Bir Slam, at the entry of Bejaia where they protested for several hours. They denounce austerity measures from the government which necessitated the shut-down of several micro-enterprises.
On the week of 7 May, transport workers protested in Laghouat to denounce the new train station situated 4km outside of Laghouat. A new protest took place the following week.

On 7 May, dozens of young people from Djaafra staged a sit-in in front of the seat of the governorate to denounce the claiming back of the stadium in the commune by a private citizen. The youth use the stadium extensively.

column7: UGTA: General Union of Algerian Workers
column17: On 8 May, railway employees affiliated with the UGTA protested in Constantine and paralysed railway traffic. They denounce the regional secretary of the railway company for having supported the governor of Constantine in the framework of the 1 May workers marches.
On 8 May, dozens of citizens of Ramdane Djamel protested in front of the city hall to denounce the delay in the provision of social housing units.
On 8 May, students from the department of veterinary sciences staged a sit-in at the university in Souk Ahras denouncing difficulties in the structuration of their studies.
On 12 May, inhabitants from the social housing city in Ain El Beida staged a protest in front of the primary school to call for the provision of electricity to the schools in the city.

On 13 May, social housing applicants from Dar Benabdellah staged a protest in front of the city hall of the village to denounce their exclusion from social housing benefits. Through being physically present they blocked the entry until gendarmiere intervened peacefully to escort the protesters away from the building.
On 13 May, transport workers protested for the second time in Laghouat to denounce the new train station situated 4km outside of Laghouat.
On 13 May, social housing applicants from Sidi Khaled staged a protest to denounce their exclusion from published social housing beneficiaries lists.

column9: CAMRA: Autonomous Medical Residents Collective; Health Workers (Algeria)
column17: On 13 May, Algerian police dispersed a sit-in by CAMRA protesters violently. Several protesters were injured. The sit-in took place in the context of a 6-month long strike by medical doctors.

column7: CAMRA: Autonomous Medical Residents Collective; Health Workers (Algeria)
column17: On 13 May, CAMRA doctors staged a sit-in in Constantine to show solidarity with their colleagues in Oran who were injured through police violence the same day.

column7: UGCAA: General Union of Algerian Merchants and Artisans
column17: On 14 May, businessmen and traders from Ouergla staged a protest in front of the directorate of commerce in Ouergla and went on a general strike to call on the lifting of sanctions that were put on them by the central government. They also call for a regularisation of informal shops in Ouargla.
On 14 May, Cevital workers and RCD party members marched in Bejaia to call on the government to deblock industrial projects and investments prohibited by the government.

On 25 June 2018, Associated Press published a story which says that in the last 14 months around 13000 sub-saharan African migrants were brought to the middle of the desert where Algerian police showed them the way to Niger. Two migrants told AP that gendarmes fired on groups to force them to walk. There are reports of several deaths. 14 VAC events coded with 10 fatalities spread across the events.

On 15 May, dozens of master students from the Institute of Islamic Civilisation in Oran protested at the faculty INSEP to call on the administration to consider their master equal to other juridicial masters as the Sharia master currently has inferior status.
During the month of May, a demonstration took place in the Smara refugee camp near Tindouf over water shortages.
During the month of May, a demonstration took place in Rabouni refugee camp, near Tindouf, in protest against the decision to withdraw Frente Polisario militia from Guerguerat.

column9: CAMRA: Autonomous Medical Residents Collective; Health Workers (Algeria)
column17: On 15 May, CAMRA doctors staged a sit-in in Algiers to show solidarity with their colleagues in Oran who were injured through police violence two days before. They were violently dispersed by police through water canons. Some were injured and arrested.
On 15 May, workers of the Algerian water center in Ain Saleh organised a protest to call for the departure of the head of the center over mismanagement and negligence.

column7: RCD: Constitutional Democratic Rally; UDS: Democratic and Social Union; LADDH: Algerian League for the Defense of Human Rights
column17: On 16 May, protesters supported by the RCD and UDS staged a protest in front of the seat of the governorate in Bejaia to show their solidarity with Ali Yahya Abdennour, a human rights defender, who was expropriated by the government.

column7: UGTA: General Union of Algerian Workers; Health Workers (Algeria)
column17: On 17 May, medical workers from a public hospital in Guelma and affiliated to the UGTA staged a sit-in to call for higher salaries.

column7: SNAPAP: National Independent Union of Public Administration Personnel; Labour Group (Algeria)
column17: Around 17 May, members of the Snapap syndicate staged a sit-in in front of the university center in Relizane because they were legally not allowed to join/adhere to the Snapap.
On 19 May, farmers from Si Safi and Si Rabah staged a sit-in in front of the prefecture in Tessala to regulate the status of the partnership between the farms, the government and the private sector.
On 20 May, people from Ramka blocked access to the prefecture in Ramka through being physically present. They protest against the ongoing deterioration of their socio-economic conditions.
On 20 May, workers from the national stud farm 'Chaou-Chaoua' in Tiaret protested because they did not receive their salaries for more than two months.
In the week of 21 May, two older Imams were found beheaded in Oued Shbaa, 70km South-East of Sidi Bel Abbes. Perpetrators were suspected Islamic extremists.

On 21 May, unemployed people from Relizane protested in front of the city hall and blocked access through being physically present. They denounce the authorities for prohibiting them from pursuing an informal business and being excluded from Ramadan bonuses.
On 22 May, inhabitants of Chechar protested against the bad quality of tap water and called for an improvement.

column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: On 29 May, Algerian military forces shot dead a militant in Hammam Righa on the provincial border between Ain Defla or Tipaza. Difficult to say whether AQIM or ISIS but signs point to AQIM.
On 30 May, workers from the prefecture in Mahdia protested to condemn the non-renewal of their working contracts.
On 30 May, social housing beneficiaries from Bouhaf Dyr organised a sit-in in front of the seat of the governorate in Tebessa to denounce the delay in the provision of social housing units.

On 31 May, an Algerian family composed of eight individuals organised a sit-in in front of the seat of the governorate in Medea to denounce their marginalisation, exclusion and socio-economic disadvantage.

On 31 May, several people protested in Aokas to call on the government to stop the unjust treatment of journalist Merzoug Touati who was imprisoned on grounds of having interviewed an Israeli diplomat. Berber people in the Kabylie believe that he was imprisoned because of his Berber origins.

column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: On 31 May, Algerian military forces shot dead an AQIM militant in Oued Bouferhat in the commune of Ouled Antar in Medea governorate.
Weapons Seizure: On 2 June the Algerian army discovered five militant hideouts with weapons and destroyed them.
In the week of 2 June, economically disadvantaged people trying to get the Ramadan aid-basket protested in front of the distribution post in Boumerdes because not enough baskets were available.
In the week of 2 June, economically disadvantaged people trying to get the Ramadan aid-basket protested in front of the distribution post in Zemmouri because not enough baskets were available.

In the week of 2 June, economically disadvantaged people trying to get the Ramadan aid-basket protested in front of the distribution post in Khemis El Khechna because not enough baskets were available.
In the week of 2 June, economically disadvantaged people trying to get the Ramadan aid-basket protested in front of the distribution post in Issers because not enough baskets were available.
In the week of 2 June, economically disadvantaged people trying to get the Ramadan aid-basket protested in front of the distribution post in Bordj Menaiel because not enough baskets were available.

On 2 June several people protested in Bouira to call on the government to stop the unjust treatment of journalist Merzoug Touati who was imprisoned on grounds of having interviewed an Israeli diplomat. Berber people in the Kabylie believe that he was imprisoned because of his Berber origins.
On 3 June, architects staged a sit-in in Tiaret to denounce the corrupt way of the government of contracting specific firms for state projects.
On 3 June workers journalists and technicians of the journal 'The Times-Algeria' held a protest outside the company's HQs in Algiers to ask for the payment of their delayed salaries.
On 4 June, inhabitants from Merahna and adjacent villages protested against the proposed plan to expand the industrial zone which would diminish the amount of arable land.
On 4 June, economically disadvantaged people trying to get the Ramadan aid-basket protested in front of the distribution post in Boumerdes because not enough baskets were available.
On 5 June, inhabitants of Tiaret protested in front of the prefecture to denounce a real-estate project in their neighbourhood.

On 5 June several people protested in Tizi Ouzou to call on the government to stop the unjust treatment of journalist Merzoug Touati who was imprisoned on grounds of having interviewed an Israeli diplomat. Berber people in the Kabylie believe that he was imprisoned because of his Berber origins.

column7: CAMRA: Autonomous Medical Residents Collective; Health Workers (Algeria)
column17: On 6 June dozens of striking doctors from the CAMRA syndicate staged a protest march in Tizi Ouzou to call for an improvement of their socio-professional situation.

On 6 June several people protested in Bejaia to call on the government to stop the unjust treatment of journalist Merzoug Touati who was imprisoned on grounds of having interviewed an Israeli diplomat. Berber people in the Kabylie believe that he was imprisoned because of his Berber origins.

column9: CAMRA: Autonomous Medical Residents Collective; Health Workers (Algeria)
column17: On 6 June, Algerian police prevented doctors from the CAMRA collective to stage a protest in Annaba and thereby injured several of them.

On the week of 9 June, a political activist and member of the Yagout tribe was allegedly killed by Polisario party cadres in Dheibya prison near Tindouf. Other sources say that the man committed suicide.
On 9 June, hundreds of women organised a protest run to condemn street harassment after a video in which a young women is attacked by a man during her jogging training surfaced in the internet.

On 10 June, a Chinese citizen was robbed and killed by criminal Algerians in broad daylight in the region of Dalbeda in Algiers. The Chinese ambassador pointed out that attacks against Chinese companies and personnel have increased significantly and issued a statement, alerting Chinese citizens in Algeria to take further safety precautions.

On 12 June, railway workers of the Directorate General of the National Corporation of Railways protested in Rouiba to call on the president and general manager of the company to reinstate the recently fired director.

On 14 June, two inspectors of the business chamber in Bouira were injured by a bakery operator in Raffour when they found the business closed after they wanted to inspect the public support that the bakery receives.

On 25 June 2018, Associated Press published a story which says that in the last 14 months around 13000 sub-saharan African migrants were brought to the middle of the desert where Algerian police showed them the way to Niger. Two migrants told AP that gendarmes fired on groups to force them to walk. There are reports of several deaths. 14 VAC events coded with 10 fatalities spread across the events.

In the week of 15 June, several people protested in Setif to call on the government to stop the unjust treatment of journalist Merzoug Touati who was imprisoned on grounds of having interviewed an Israeli diplomat. Berber people in the Kabylie believe that he was imprisoned because of his Berber origins.

16-25 June, dozens of people from the Yagou tribe staged a sit-in near the home of Polisario leader Ibrahim Ghali to protest against the organisation's violent crackdown on political dissidents. The 60 protesters demanded an investigation into the hanging of a fellow tribesman and political activist whose body was found earlier this month after he was killed/committed suicide in Dheibya prison. On the last two days, the Polisario Front shot at the protesters and arrested some but no-one was injured.

column7: CAMRA: Autonomous Medical Residents Collective; Health Workers (Algeria)
column17: On 17 June, doctors from the CAMRA organised a protest at the CHU hospital in Bab El Oued after 30 of their colleagues were fired for striking. The strike of the CAMRA hs been lasting for more than 8 months.

column7: CAMRA: Autonomous Medical Residents Collective; Health Workers (Algeria)
column17: On 17 June, doctors from the CAMRA organised a protest in Oran after 800 of their colleagues were fired for striking. The strike of the CAMRA lasts for more than 8 months already.

column7: CAMRA: Autonomous Medical Residents Collective; Health Workers (Algeria)
column17: On 17 June, doctors from the CAMRA organised a protest in Constantine after 800 of their colleagues were fired for striking. The strike of the CAMRA lasts for more than 8 months already.

column7: CAMRA: Autonomous Medical Residents Collective; Health Workers (Algeria)
column17: On 17 June, doctors from the CAMRA organised a protest in Annaba after 800 of their colleagues were fired for striking. The strike of the CAMRA lasts for more than 8 months already.

On 18 June several people protested in Naciria to call on the government to stop the unjust treatment of journalist Merzoug Touati who was imprisoned on grounds of having interviewed an Israeli diplomat. Berber people in the Kabylie believe that he was imprisoned because of his Berber origins.

On 20 June, fifty workers from the local commercial chamber in Bouira protested in front of the directorate to denounce the physcial violence against two of their colleagues when they were doing a check on public support for a bakery which they found closed.

On 21 June several people protested in front of the court of justice in Bejaia on the day of the trial start. The demonstrators, members of the 'Comittee for the liberation of Merzoug Touati', call on the government to stop the unjust treatment of journalist Merzoug Touati who was imprisoned on grounds of having interviewed an Israeli diplomat. Berber people in the Kabylie believe that he was imprisoned because of his Berber origins. Police dispersed the protest and arrested 40 protesters without clashes and injuries.

On 24 June, according to Polisario critic Mustapaha Salama, the Polisario Front tried to kill a Sahrawi dissident, Rabbas Abdelrahman Yahdeh. They shot him while he was in a car in the outskirts of the Laayoune camp near Tindouf but he survived. Another dissident was found dead after having been tortured in Polisario-run D'Heibya prison last week. These reports surface amid the visit of UN special envoy to Western Sahara Horst Kohler to Algeria.

16-25 June, dozens of people from the Yagou tribe staged a sit-in near the home of Polisario leader Ibrahim Ghali to protest against the organisation's violent crackdown on political dissidents. The 60 protesters demanded an investigation into the hanging of a fellow tribesman and political activist whose body was found earlier this month after he was killed/committed suicide in Dheibya prison. On the last two days, the Polisario Front shot at the protesters and arrested some but no-one was injured.

16-25 June, dozens of people from the Yagou tribe staged a sit-in near the home of Polisario leader Ibrahim Ghali to protest against the organisation's violent crackdown on political dissidents. The 60 protesters demanded an investigation into the hanging of a fellow tribesman and political activist whose body was found earlier this month after he was killed/committed suicide in Dheibya prison. On the last two days, the Polisario Front shot at the protesters and arrested some but no-one was injured.

column7: SNAPAP: National Independent Union of Public Administration Personnel
column17: On 25 June, workers from the directorate of housing in Constantine governorate and members of the SNAPAP protested against the new director in Constantine, accusing him of refusing any dialogue with the syndicate members.

Non-violent activity: On 26 June, Algerian president Bouteflika fired the head of the police forces and directorate of national security (DGSN) Abdelghani Hameel. No official reason was given but it is suspected that he could have been involved in a recent drug scandal (701kg of Cocaine were seized at the port of Oran last month)

column7: CNFD: National Coordination of the Families of the Missing
column17: On 26 June, arond 50 people from the National Coordination of Families of the Disappeared (CNFD) protested in Bachir Bennacer square in Constantine to show their support with political prisoners who disappeared during the 'black decade' (90s). They ask for answers to the question of what happened to their children. Police forces violently tried to prevent them holding their sit-in but no injuries were reported.
In the week of 1 July, clashes between religious groups vying for control of a mosque in Chlef province took place.
On 1 July, social housing applicants from Diar Ezzitoune in Azzaba city protested in front of the prefecture to call for a swift completion of promised social housing units.

On 2 July, families from the Napolitanian quarter in Skikda barricaded three main roads to call for an improvement of their living situation, considering their situation worse than the one of social housing beneficiaries in the suburbs.
On 2 July, workers from the 'Direction des oeuvres universitaires' (DOU) staged a sit-in to protest against their exclusion and marginalisation with regards to job promotion.

Security Measures: On 4 July, Algerian president Bouteflika fired the head of the national gendarmerie Menad Nouba and the head of Algiers security, Noureddine Berrachedi. Bouteflika had fired the head of the police forces and directorate of national security (DGSN) Abdelghani Hameel the week before. No official reason was given but it is suspected that they could have been involved in a recent scandal: 701kg of Cocaine were seized at the port of Oran last month.
On 4 July, inhabitants of Mehagga village in Idjeur protested in front of the prefecture, preventing access to the offices. Protesters callled for structural development of the village.

On 4 July, inhabitants from Ain Youcef blocked the road RN 22 to call for structural development of their neighbourhood, especially in light of the recent establishment of the El Graba suburb which they consider much better equipped than their neighbourhood.
On 5 July, citizens from Bechar clashed with police forces after the citizens initially protested against i.a. tap-water- and electricity cuts.
On 5 July, citizens from El Meghayer blocked the road with tires and closed down the municipality to protest against unjust distribution of social housing units.
On 5 July, citizens from Jijel blocked the road to the beach with burning tires to protest against the high fees for parking and umbrellas.
On 6 July, inhabitants from Bechar protested for the second day in a row, this time peacefully. They condemn water shortages and ambiguity of the distribution of state-funded social housing.

Around 6 July, inhabitants of social housing cities in Mahelma set up blocks on the road linking Mahelma with Rahmania and Douira because of the interruption in tap water service for more than 10 days.
On 8 July, dozens of people protested in front of the municipality in Adrar over the ambiguity of the distribution of social housing and lack of drinking water.
On 10 July, inhabitants of Djanet protested for an improved access to tap water and electricity in light of the high temperatures above 50 degree celcius.

Movement of forces: On 11 July, after the recent attack by AQIM on Tunisian security forces, nearly 2000 Algerian soldiers have participated in a military operation to sweep the provinces of Tebessa, Souk Ahras and al Oued, which are adjacent to Tunisian territories, to prevent the infiltration of militants during their pursuit by the Tunisian forces.

Movement of forces: On 11 July, after the recent attack by AQIM on Tunisian security forces, nearly 2000 Algerian soldiers have participated in a military operation to sweep the provinces of Tebessa, Souk Ahras and al Oued, which are adjacent to Tunisian territories, to prevent the infiltration of militants during their pursuit by the Tunisian forces.

Movement of forces: On 11 July, after the recent attack by AQIM on Tunisian security forces, nearly 2000 Algerian soldiers have participated in a military operation to sweep the provinces of Tebessa, Souk Ahras and al Oued, which are adjacent to Tunisian territories, to prevent the infiltration of militants during their pursuit by the Tunisian forces.
On 12 July, people protested at Ben Redouane station in Algiers to call for an improvement of their socio-economic conditions.

column7: CAMRA: Autonomous Medical Residents Collective; Health Workers (Algeria)
column17: On 14 July, dozens of medical workers and doctors from the CAMRA protested in front of the Mustapha Pasha hospital in Algiers to condemn the non-payment of salaries despite the CAMRA ending their strike on 26 June.

On 15 July, dozens of Algerian Protestant Church (EPA) worshippers protested in Riquet (now Colonel Amirouche), Akbou, against the decision by the administration and security forces to close a church over the lack of authorisation.
On 16 July, inhabitants of Ath Mansour, east of Bouira, protested the lack of access to tap water. Their presence forced the local prefecture to shut down.
On 16 July, inhabitants of Djanet protested to denounce electricity cuts since the end of May leading to problems because of the high temperatures.
On 16 July, inhabitants of Adrar protested to denounce electricity cuts leading to problems because of the high temperatures.

On 17 July, retired army personnel from all over the country demonstrated in Dar El Beida, Rouiba and Kharrouba to march towards the center of Algiers before clashing with police forces who used tear gas. Several people were injured. Protesters demand higher pensions.

On 17 July, retired army personnel from all over the country demonstrated in Dar El Beida, Rouiba and Kharrouba to march towards the center of Algiers before clashing with police forces who used tear gas. Several people were injured. Protesters demand higher pensions.

On 17 July, retired army personnel from all over the country demonstrated in Dar El Beida, Rouiba and Kharrouba to march towards the center of Algiers before clashing with police forces who used tear gas. Several people were injured. Protesters demand higher pensions.
On 18 July, inhabitants of Tamda village blocked the main road on the height of El Kseur to call for an improvement of their socio-economic conditions. They also threw stones at a train.
In the week of 18 July, inhabitants of Illizi protested to denounce electricity cuts leading to problems because of the high temperatures.
In the week of 18 July, inhabitants of Ouargla protested to denounce electricity cuts leading to problems because of the high temperatures.
On 21 July, inhabitants in Bechar staged a sit-in against a music concert because they see it as a waste of money which could better be used for economic development. The event was cancelled.

On 22 July, unemployed residents of Ouargla protested against high electricity prices due to the heat wave and for better access to tap water. Protesters clashed with police which led to several injuries.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Agreement: Around 22 July a number of AQIM militants fighting in Libya reportedly surrendered to the Algerian army after arrangements with guarantees were made.

On 22 July, protesters held protests in Maghnia to demand the reopening of border crossings to Morocco and the reunion of families split up by its closure. Gendarmerie was present and prevented a journalist from properly covering the protest.
On 23 July, workers from EURL GAEA China protested in Oran to call for the payment of delayed salaries.
On 23 July, several thousand workers staged a sit-in in front of the Sonatrach company to call for a re-classification of their legal status which would improve their socio-economic conditions.
In the week of 25 July, farmer protested in Sidi Makhlouf to call for a proper electrification of the village.

Non-violent activity: On 23 July, President Bouteflika conducted a reshuffle of civil protection forces, replacing ten regional directors and dismissing the directory of security for Ouargla, Ghardaia and Laghouat. The police officer responsible to secure Algiers airport was also dismissed.

23 July-16 August: four weeks of protests by Sonatrach employees in Hassi R'Mel to call on the company to put them on the same salary scale as other colleagues. Coded as four events between 23 July and 16 August.

On 24 July, residents of Ouargla protested over electricity price rises, high unemployent rates and a record-breaking heatwave. Protesters demand the government fo exempt the area from the payment of electricity bills in light of the high temperatures.
On 24 July, citizens and members of the FLN closed the prefecture through being physically present to protest against a decision by the local mayor.
In the week of 25 July, social housing applicants blocked the road in Raffour to protest their exclusion from newly published social housing beneficiaries lists.
In the week of 25 July, social housing applicants blocked the road in Assif Assemad/Oued el Bared to protest their exclusion from newly published social housing beneficiaries lists.
On 25 and 26 July, citizens and members of the FLN protested in Taghzout against a decision of the local mayor. The protest led to the closure of the prefecture.

On 26 July, inhabitants of Ath Leksar protested in front of the local police station to denounce rampant insecurity in the village after a mentally handicapped women was kidnapped and liberated only two days later.
On 26 July, micro-credit debitors organised a protest in Tizi Ouzou to call for the cancellation of their debts which they received under state-run ANSEJ, CNAC and ANGEM programs.
On 25 and 26 July, citizens and members of the FLN protested in Taghzout against a decision of the local mayor. The protest led to the closure of the prefecture.

On 26 July, residents of Ouargla protested over electricity price rises, high unemployent rates and a record-breaking heatwave. Protesters demand the government fo exempt the area from the payment of electricity bills in light of the high temperatures. They also ask for access to tap water and improvement of infrastructure. A concert also had to be cancalled as protesters considered it to be a waste of money.
On 28 July, dozens of social housing applicants protested in Tizi Ouzou to call for a swift completion of promised social housing units.

On 29 July, Berber protesters staged a sit-in in front of the prison in Oued Ghir in Bejaia to call for the release of blogger Merzoug Touati. He was condemned to 7 years prison last June after being accused of conspiring against Algeria.

On 29 July, citizens protested in Djelfa to denounce a 'policy of discrimination' against the Djelfa region, which they claim is deprived of development projects. At the same time, protesters condemned the authorities' lack of response to the death of a war veteran and commander of the gendarmerie.

23 July-16 August: four weeks of protests by Sonatrach employees in Hassi R'Mel to call on the company to put them on the same salary scale as other colleagues. Coded as four events between 23 July and 16 August.
On 31 July, inhabitants from Takana closed the Algerian water agency in Ain El Hammam to protest their lack of access to tap water for more than two months.
Defusal: On 31 July, the Algerian gendarmerie defused a bomb near a beach in Corso, Boumerdes. No more info on the potential perpetrators was given.

column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: On 31 July, seven soldiers and four AQIM militants were killed in clashes in the locality of Bessi, Skikda, during a search and sweep operation. 10 others were injured.
On 1 August, residents of Sidi Bel Abbes held a protest against a Rai music festival.

On 1 August, citizens and civil society activists staged a sit-in in Ath Laksar to denounce the transformation of the local library and commercial buildings into administrative buildings of the prefecture.
On 2 August, dozens of Bejaia residents staged a sit-in against illicit constructions on the seaside. Protesters called on the government to stop this business.

column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: On 2 August, the Algerian military carried out airstrikes against presumed AQIM militants in the mountains of Bissy (Azzaba), Skikda, two days after AQIM militants killed seven Algerian soldiers in an attack in the same area.
On 5 August, dozens of social housing beneficiaries in Merj Eddib, Skikda protested to call on the government to swiftly provide promised housing units.

23 July-16 August: four weeks of protests by Sonatrach employees in Hassi R'Mel to call on the company to put them on the same salary scale as other colleagues. Coded as four events between 23 July and 16 August.
On 8 August, social housing beneficiaries in Skikda held a sit-in to call on the government to swiftly provide promised housing units.
In the week of 8 August, inhabitants of Tebessa protested on one of the main streets for several hours because of the lack of access to tap water.
On 10 August, two assailants attacked and injured a journalist of 'Le Matin d'Algerie' newspaper in Tiaret, reportedly because of his political activism.
On 11 August, inhabitants of Bab Essour in Jijel staged a sit-in to denounce the plan to build a public toilet opposite of their homes.
On 11 August, the Katiba Salaheddine (ISGS) founder and leader Sultan Ould Bady surrendered to the Algerian military in Tamanrasset.

On 12 August, activists from the Mouwatana (our Homeland) movement protested on the martyrs square in Algiers against a prospective fifth mandate of President Bouteflika. Police dispersed the sit-in and arrested several movement leaders.

On 12 August, inhabitants of Biskra protested in front of the seat of the municipality to denounce the construction of a new date market because the private investor kicked out the locals from the market.
On 12 August, workers at the Tichihaf dam blocked the CW43 at Tarakabt in Bordj Bou Arreridj with their cars and tractors to denounce the delay in the payment of their salaries.

On 13 August, social housing applicants staged a sit-in in front of the local offices for the distribution of social housing to denounce high bills and calling for concessions as were given to Southern regions.

23 July-16 August: four weeks of protests by Sonatrach employees in Hassi R'Mel to call on the company to put them on the same salary scale as other colleagues. Coded as four events between 23 July and 16 August.
On 13 August, health workers from the Alia Salah hospital in Tebessa staged a sit-in in front of the hospital to denounce the mismanagement of the hospital by the director.
On 14 August, inhabitants of Bouhemza who initially planned to block the Tichy-Haf dam instead protested on the main road leading from Bouhemza to Akbou. Inhabitants denounce the lack of tap water.
On 14 August, 15 unemployed residents of Ouargla staged a sit-in and threatened to kill themselves because of the dire situation. Ouargla is a key region for oil and gas production.
On 14 August, hotel workers from PTT hotels staged a sit-in to denounce the non-payment of salaries for 11 months.
On 15 August, unemployed citizens protested in front of the Cosider public offices in El Mahmel to call for employment in the agricultural department of the company.
On 16 August, inhabitants of Chaaba Hamra in Djidiouia protested on the road to denounce the pollution caused by the nearby waste dump.

Non-violent activity: On 16 August, President Bouteflika fired the commanders of the 1st and 2nd military regions, Habib Chentouf and Said Bey. A week later, the commander of the 4th military region Abderrazak Cherif, and the head of the Central Security of the Army (DCSA) Mohamed Tireche were also fired. In the last weeks several military and police officers, among them the head of the national gendarmerie, have been fired.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: On 17 August, 2 children died as an IED exploded near them in Ahnif. Four other children were seriously injured. AQIM reportedly planted the bomb to stop the advancement of Algerian military forces who chase the militants in the mountains.
On 17 August, inhabitants of Tazaghart near Azeffun marched on the road to Tizi-Ouzou to denounce recurrent electricity cuts.
On 18 August, Algerian military shot an alleged smuggler near the Libyan border at Djanet. Djanet residents say the man was from Djanet and protested the following days.

On 19 August, Djanet residents blocked roads with burning tires and threw stones at the military to denounce the death of a smuggler from the village at the hands of the Algerian military. The military responded with shooting at the protesters leading to several dead. Low estimated fatality count coded as 3.

On 19 August, dozens of residents near Ahnif protested on a motorway, demanding minesweeping operations to be conducted in their areas after an IED killed two children and injured four others two days before.
On 19 August, hundreds of citizens gathered at a concert in the town of Ain El Hadjel and conducted prayers in protest against lack of economic development, preventing the concert from taking place.
On 19 August, social housing applicants protested to denounce the delay in the provision of promised social housing units.
On 20 August, Djanet residents protested to denounce the military killing several rioters from Djanet the day before. The situation has calmed down after a negotiated agreement.
On 20 August, activists and friends of the recently liberated Berber journalist Merzoug Touati staged a protest in support of free speech in Ouzellaguen.

On 25 August, inhabitants of Ahmed Salem in Kerkera blocked the main road with burning tires and branches to denounce irregularities with the recently published list of local social housing allocations.
On 26 August, dozens of citizens marched between Sidi El Houari and Ras el Ain neighbourhoods in Oran to denounce perturbations in the provision of tap water in the two neighbourhoods.
On 26 August, the Algerian military shot dead a local smuggler in In Guezzam leading to protests on August 26th and 27th (protests coded in separate events).
On 26 August, inhabitants of In Guezzam protested after the ANP shot dead a local smuggler.
On 27 August, inhabitants of In Guezzam protested after the ANP shot dead a local smuggler the day before.

Non-violent activity: On 27 August, the re-shuffle in the Algerian military continued. The commander of the fourth military region, Ouargla, was sent into retirement whereas the head of the third military region was promoted to head of the ground forces. Almost all senior commanders have been either sent into retirement or put into different positions in recent weeks.
On 27 August, inhabitants of Planteurs neighbourhood protested in Oran against the lack of tap water.
On 28 August, inhabitants of Aissat Idir neighbourhood in Relizane protested against the delay in the reconstruction of roads in their neighbourhood.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Agreement: In the week of 29 August, two AQIM militants, both known for recruiting militants in the South of Algeria for AQIM, surrendered in Tamanrasset to the Algerian military. Defections have been recurrent in recent weeks, after a deal for surrendering terrorists has been set up by the Algerian military with the help of France.
In the week of 29 August, inhabitants of Bessekra and Guelaftia staged a protest in Chlef to denounce the lack of tap water in their villages.

On 30 August, families of people who were forcibly disappeared in the 90s gathered in Algiers on the 'International Day of Enforced Disappearances' to call on the government to clarify the status of their relatives. Police was present to prevent protesters from marching and others from joining the initial bulk of protesters.
On 31 August, farmers and retired Algerians who worked in France protested in front of BADR bank in Oued Rhiu because of its poor retirement payments.

On 31 August, inhabitants of the Cite Ben M'Hidi in Skikda blocked a construction site which aims to supply the commune with tap water, arguing that their neighbourhood is sufficiently supplied with water from water wells and water lines. They instead call for using the money for other public infrastructure projects of which the neighbourhood would profit more.

Weapons seizure: On September 1st, the Algerian military seized a small quantity of weapons, seven homemade bombs and seven kilos of TNT during a weapons sweep at three locations (Medea, Bordj Badji Mokhtar, and In Guezzam; coordinates for Medea used).
On 1 September, workers of construction company SOMACOB in Bejaia organised a protest to express their anger over the administration's deliberate delay of paying wages.
On 1 September, inhabitants of Beni Said, a suburb of Collo, staged a sit-in in front of the prefecture to denounce the recently published list of social housing and to call for a new list.

Movement of forces: On or before September 2nd, around 300 soldiers were reported to have been deployed in the mountains of Bouira, and moving around the villages of El Zaouia and Ouled El Hadj (coordinates for Bouira used). A small number of IS militants are reported to be in the area.

On 2 September, the CAMRA reportedly re-launched its protest movement in Algiers, condemning the government's non-implementation of their previous promises on meeting their professional and social demands in exchange for stopping their protests carried out during the past months.
On 2 September, inhabitants of Chehairia blocked the road between Relizane and Tiaret at Sidi Lazreg with burning tires and branches to denounce bad roads and lack of tap water in their village.

On 2 September, social housing beneficiaries from Ain El Beida protested in the entry to their cities to call for the opening of a road connecting their village better and denouncing the lack of gas and electricity.
On 2 September, workers in industrial zone Hassi Ameur east of Oran organised a protest in front of a company that is endangered to go bankrupt.
On 2 September, social housing applicants streamed to public buildings to call for a swift completion of promised social housing units.

On 3 September, Islamist militants fired on soldiers during a patrol in the village of Talagh. Later that day 3 soldiers died and 4 were injured as they stepped on a landmine by the militants. In the end they tracked down the militants in Tafassour and killed two of them. Split up into two events.

On 3 September, Islamist militants fired on soldiers during a patrol in the village of Talagh. Later that day 3 soldiers died and 4 were injured as they stepped on a landmine by the militants. In the end they tracked down the militants in Tafassour and killed two of them. Split up into two events.

Arrests: On or before September 4th, the Algerian army arrested 12 suspected terrorists (affiliation unspecified), with nine of the arrests taking place at In Guezzam (note the source also states that some of these were arrested at Tamanghasset; coordinates for In Guezzam used). The nine men arrested in this area were said to be armed, whilst three other detainees were arrested in Setif, on suspicion of supporting terrorist groups.
On 5 September, medical workers organised a sit-in in front of the Ministry of Tertiary Education to call for a repetition of a diploma exam for colleagues who had failed it.

On 5 September, angry parents of pupils went to school with their children in Skikda and then left school with them as a sign of protest. Young teachers also stayed at home for the first few days of schooling. The parents are unsatisfied with the director of the El-Ghazali school.

column6: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: Agreement: In the week of 5 September, 3 AQIM militants surrendered to the Algerian army in Tamanrasset. Surrenders have been facilitated through a deal strought by the Algerian army in coordination with the French government.

On Sept 6, a number of Polisario Gendarmerie elite forces staged a protest in front of the organisation's HQs in Rabouni, located around 25 kilometers south of Tindouf, to denounce their training conditions, which include for instance intermittent water and electricity supply.

On 6 September, residents of Ouargla protested in front of the local directorate of health and then staged a protest march to call for a better quality of health services. Some days before a woman died from a scorpion sting despite having been transferred to a local hospital.
On 7 September, inhabitants of Planteurs neighbourhood protested in Oran against the lack of tap water. They blocked the road between Sidi El Houari and Ras El Ain through physically protesting.

On 8 September, activists from the Mouwatana movement wanted to protest in Constantine but were blocked from doing so by police who moved dumpsters and trucks into the city's main squares to prevent the protest from happening. A number of activists were arrests.
Weapons seizure: During the week beginning Sunday 9th September, military forces seized two weapons caches in In Guezzam (Tamanghasset). The seizures took place on September 10th and September 15th.

On September 12th, medical students demonstrated outside the Ministry of Education in Algiers, in protest of the refusal of the Ministry to allow many students to complete their degree, owing to strike action they had undertaken.

Arrests: During the week beginning Sunday 9th September, the Algerian army arrested a number of suspected terrorists (allegiance unspecified). Two were arrested in Sidi Bel Abbes (coordinates used) on 9th Sep; two in Tamanrasset on 11th Sep; one in Adrar on 13th Sep; and one in Tizi Ouzou, again on 13th Sep.

In September, a number of Arab students organised a gathering in Jiljel to protest against the compulsory teaching of Tamazight. No police/military intervention was reported. Further protests reported mid October.

On September 15th, protesters (estimated at between 5,000 and 25,000 in number) demonstrated against the lack of development (particularly with regards to water and sanitation infrastructure, and jobs), in Ouargla. A group of protesters clashed with the police, with police firing tear gas at the crowd. Two protesters were wounded in the clash.

On September 15th, police prevented a demonstration by Mouwatana Mouvement activists from taking place in Bejaia. They detained a number of the activists, and reportedly beat several of them with truncheons.

column8: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
column17: On 19 September. Military forces killed two dangerous terrorists (likely AQIM) and recovered two Kalashnikov-type machine guns and a quantity of ammunition in Collo.
On 19 September. Workers of a Spanish petrochemicals manufacturer hold a sit in protest over labour issues in El Bouni.
On 20 September. Residents of a housing estate on the ""Boumerdes coast"" protested, preventing construction workers access to a camp building site.
In the night between Sept 23 and 24 a paramedic was beaten by unknown individuals at the Bouira health centre. This triggered protests on October 2nd (coded in a separate event).

On 23 September, thousands of army retirees protested in the Haouch al-Makhfi district of Algiers. The gendarmerie forces forcibly dispersed the protest, leading to clashes between the protesters and the security forces that left an unknown number of people injured.
On 26 September, a so-called ""terrorist"" known as Abou Khaled surrendered to the Algerian military in Tamanrasset in Tamenghasset in Algeria.

On 27 September, four terrorist bunkers, two homemade bombs, foodstuff and other items were discovered and destroyed in Tipaza district, Chlef district and Tizi Ouzou district by a detachment of the Algerian army.

From 30th September to 3rd October, people protested in Khemis Miliana (Ain Defla) against the exclusion of over 1,000 residents from public housing, preventing access on the road and rail infrastructure.

From 30th September to 3rd October, people protested in Khemis Miliana (Ain Defla) against the exclusion of over 1,000 residents from public housing, preventing access on the road and rail infrastructure.

column7: UGTA: General Union of Algerian Workers; SNPSSP: National union of Special Practitioners of Public Health Algeria; Health Workers (Algeria)
column17: On Oct 2, the staff of the Public Institution of Local Health (EPSP) of the town of Bouira protested in front of the town hospital denouncing the ""repetitive verbal and physical aggression"" experienced in their work-life.

From 30th September to 3rd October, people protested in Khemis Miliana (Ain Defla) against the exclusion of over 1,000 residents from public housing, preventing access on the road and rail infrastructure.
On Oct 3, the National People's Army discovered and destroyed two homemade bombs in Ain Defla.

From 30th September to 3rd October, people protested in Khemis Miliana (Ain Defla) against the exclusion of over 1,000 residents from public housing, preventing access on the road and rail infrastructure.
On October 3rd, health workers gathered at the hospital in Bouira town, to protest violence directed against staff.

During the week beginning October 1st, Algerian soldiers seized several bunkers and weapons caches belonging to unspecified ""terrorists"". On 1st Oct, the military destroyed six bunkers in Boumerdes (coordinates used), and seized weapons in Tamanrasset. On 3rd Oct, two homemade bombs were disarmed in Ain Defla province, whilst on Oct 4th three bunkers were destroyed in Batna.
On October 7, dozens of citizens of Rouiba village in the municipality of Ain Lahdjar (Bouira) protested demanding the improvement of their living conditions.
On Oct 8, around fifty people organized a march in the town of M'chedallah denouncing the delay in the completion of the 120-bed hospital in the same municipality.
On Oct 13, two children died as a result of the explosion of a landmine and two others were injured in Hassi Zerrouki, between the communes of Sidi Djilali and Aricha, in the south of Tlemcen.

column7: Students (Algeria); CLA: High Schools Council of Algeria
column17: On Oct 14, students protested in Boumerdes, Bouira, Batna and Constantine after their applications to start Master courses were rejected.

column7: Students (Algeria); CLA: High Schools Council of Algeria
column17: On Oct 14, students protested in Boumerdes, Bouira, Batna and Constantine after their applications to start Master courses were rejected.

column7: Students (Algeria); CLA: High Schools Council of Algeria
column17: On Oct 14, students protested in Boumerdes, Bouira, Batna and Constantine after their applications to start Master courses were rejected.

column7: Students (Algeria); CLA: High Schools Council of Algeria
column17: On Oct 14, students protested in Boumerdes, Bouira, Batna and Constantine after their applications to start Master courses were rejected.

On Oct 15, students of the departments of electronics, mechanics and engineering at the Saad Dahlab Univerversity, in the Ouled Yaich area of Blida wilaya, launched a protest and a subsequent strike against the newly established electronic registration system for Masters degrees. A number of students failed to get into Masters programmes, reportedly because of the system.

On Nov 5, the Algerian army claimed to have arrested 1 ""terrorist"" and 34 elements that provided ""terrorist support"" during the previous month of October. It also claimed that 10 other ""terrorists"" had handed themselves in. Although the army used the term ""terrorist"", it did not provide further details about the affiliations of the people arrested.

column7: FLN: National Liberation Front; MPA: Algerian Popular Movement; RND: National Rally for Democracy; TAJ: Tajamou Amel Al Djazair
column17: On Oct 16, around a hundred deputies, members of FLN-RND-TAJ-MPA majority, gathered in front of the main entrance of the Parliament and placed a metal chain padlock on the access door to prevent Said Bouhadja, Speaker of the Lower House of Parliament, from entering the building. The protest continued the next day (coded in a separate event).

column7: UGTA: General Union of Algerian Workers
column17: On Oct 16, around 600 workers gathered in front of the National Institution for General Achievement in Annaba demanding the dissolution of the Union. They accused the General Independent Union of Algerian Workers to be illegally appointed by recommendation and not according to the workers interests and will.

column7: FLN: National Liberation Front; MPA: Algerian Popular Movement; RND: National Rally for Democracy; TAJ: Tajamou Amel Al Djazair
column17: On Oct 17, deputies from the FLN-RND-TAJ-MPA majority protested for the second day against Said Bouhadja, Speaker of the Lower House of Parliament.

On Oct 18, demonstrations broke out in Bouria during the trial of a 17-year-old accused of destruction of public property and property of others amongst others during protests in December 2017. The new protest convinced the judge to postpone the trial.
On Oct 21, a number of students took to the streets of Azazga and Gouzeguene in wilaya Tizi Ouzou, to show their refusal to study Arabic.
On Oct 21, a number of students took to the streets of Azazga and Gouzeguene in wilaya Tizi Ouzou, to show their refusal to study Arabic.

column7: Former Military Forces of Algeria (1999-) Municipal Guard
column17: On Oct 22, more than a hundred former communal guards from across the country gathered in front of the HQs of the communal guard delegation in Bouira, calling out the government for not addressing their demands (higher pensions and medical assistance for conditions that are direct results of the war).

On Oct 22, a number of journalists and human rights activists gathered in front of the Taher Djaout Press House, in El Hamma neighbourhood of Algiers, to protest against the imprisonment of fellow journalist Said Chitour, who had been detained for more than 16 months without trial.

On Oct 22, a number of students took to the streets of the Tizi Ouzou wilaya to show their refusal to study Arabic. Students showed their discontent in the towns of Azazga and Bouzeguene (for the second consecutive day), Tigzirt, Ouadhia, Maatka and Tizi Gheniff.

On Oct 22, a number of students took to the streets of the Tizi Ouzou wilaya to show their refusal to study Arabic. Students showed their discontent in the towns of Azazga and Bouzeguene (for the second consecutive day), Tigzirt, Ouadhia, Maatka and Tizi Gheniff.

On Oct 22, a number of students took to the streets of the Tizi Ouzou wilaya to show their refusal to study Arabic. Students showed their discontent in the towns of Azazga and Bouzeguene (for the second consecutive day), Tigzirt, Ouadhia, Maatka and Tizi Gheniff.

Director of online newspaper Alger-Direct Adlene Mellah was released on Nov 22 after spending around one month in jail. When released, he explained that following his arrest, he was beaten up and was subject to enhanced interrogation during 75 hours in the gendarmerie of Bab Jdid in Algiers.

On Oct 22, a number of students took to the streets of the Tizi Ouzou wilaya to show their refusal to study Arabic. Students showed their discontent in the towns of Azazga and Bouzeguene (for the second consecutive day), Tigzirt, Ouadhia, Maatka and Tizi Gheniff.

On Oct 22, a number of students took to the streets of the Tizi Ouzou wilaya to show their refusal to study Arabic. Students showed their discontent in the towns of Azazga and Bouzeguene (for the second consecutive day), Tigzirt, Ouadhia, Maatka and Tizi Gheniff.

On Oct 22, a number of students took to the streets of the Tizi Ouzou wilaya to show their refusal to study Arabic. Students showed their discontent in the towns of Azazga and Bouzeguene (for the second consecutive day), Tigzirt, Ouadhia, Maatka and Tizi Gheniff.

Military forces reportedly found and destroyed a bomb-making workshop of unknown origin, which contained 11 home-made bombs and other explosives, in Tizi Ouzou (unclear from the source if the city or the wilaya). No casualties were reported.

On Oct 24, a number of students took to the streets of the Tizi Ouzou wilaya to show their refusal to study Arabic. Students showed their discontent in the towns of Beni Zmenzer, Tizi Rached, Larbaa Nath Irathen, Ouadhia, and Illoula Oumalou.

On Oct 24, a number of students took to the streets of the Tizi Ouzou wilaya to show their refusal to study Arabic. Students showed their discontent in the towns of Beni Zmenzer, Tizi Rached, Larbaa Nath Irathen, Ouadhia, and Illoula Oumalou.

On Oct 24, a number of students took to the streets of the Tizi Ouzou wilaya to show their refusal to study Arabic. Students showed their discontent in the towns of Beni Zmenzer, Tizi Rached, Larbaa Nath Irathen, Ouadhia, and Illoula Oumalou.

On Oct 24, a number of students took to the streets of the Tizi Ouzou wilaya to show their refusal to study Arabic. Students showed their discontent in the towns of Beni Zmenzer, Tizi Rached, Larbaa Nath Irathen, Ouadhia, and Illoula Oumalou.

On Oct 24, a number of students took to the streets of the Tizi Ouzou wilaya to show their refusal to study Arabic. Students showed their discontent in the towns of Beni Zmenzer, Tizi Rached, Larbaa Nath Irathen, Ouadhia, and Illoula Oumalou.

On Oct 24, a number of residents of the Abdelmalik Kitouni avenue in Constantine took the street for several hours, to denounce the delay with which police forces responded to criminal acts (mostly the vandalising of cars) in the street the night before.

On Oct 27, a number of residents from the ""Lac des oiseaux"" impoverished area, located just south of Skikda, tried to force entry into the Abderrezak Bouhara hospital in protest at being excluded from housing beneficiary lists.

On Oct 28, around 20 young unemployed Algerians from the Negrine commune staged a protest in front of a company operating in the Mamouthia area asking for jobs. The Gendarmerie intervened and arrested 6 protesters.

On 28 October, civil society organisations in Deldoul protested in front of the prefecture to denounce the lack of protection of land, lack of transparency in the allocation of social housing and lack of dialogue.

On Oct 28, Algerian army forces discovered an important weapons cache in Bordj Baji Mokhtar, located by the border with Mali. The equipment that was found - of unknown origin - included machine guns, assault rifles and anti-tank missiles.

On Oct 29 and 30, hundreds of people protested in the Negrine commune after the arrest of 6 unemployed people from the region on Oct 28, as they staged a protest asking for jobs. Anti-riot gendarmerie forces were deployed but no interaction with protesters was reported.

On Oct 29 and 30, hundreds of people protested in the Negrine commune after the arrest of 6 unemployed people from the region on Oct 28, as they staged a protest asking for jobs. Anti-riot gendarmerie forces were deployed but no interaction with protesters was reported.
On Oct 31, the Mouwatana Mouvement coordinator in Constantine, Abdelkarim Zeghileche, was arrested by police forces. Official reasons for the arrest had yet to be disclosed as of November 3.

On Nov 1, Soltane Hriga was arrested by Gendarmerie forces after a drunken altercation with them. He reported to have been beaten up during the night the next day, and died of his injuries in Merouana hospital the day after.
On 1 November, national gendarmerie reportedly tortured a 26-year old after he had been arrested for being drunk in public.

On Nov 3, dozens of Algerians - 3,000 according to the organisers and hundreds according to another source - took to the streets of Ouargla in a protest organised by the city's civil society committee. The protesters called for local development efforts and for unfreezing a number of infrastructure projects in the city and denounced its high unemployment rate.

On Nov 3, the Algerian army claimed to have ambushed and killed Sahli Ali (aka Abou al Baraa) in the Kerkera area of Skikda wilaya. Reports presented Ali as a ""terrorist"" who had joined ""terrorist groups"" in 2010 but failed to give more specific information about his affiliations.

column9: FLN: National Liberation Front; Government of Algeria (1999-)
column17: On Nov 4, a local FLN deputy assaulted the mayor of Bensekrane, also from the FLN, following a heated debate in the local assembly. The mayor was transferred to the hospital.

On Nov 5, a number of people from the wilaya of Constantine gathered to its eponym capital to protest not having been affected social housings while some of them had handed in their applications more than 20 years ago.
On Nov 5, dozens of residents from Tassadane (northwest of Mila) gathered in front of the wilaya's HQs to protest against the deterioration of a road linking Tassadane to Lintaya.

On the night between Nov 4 and Nov 5, a number of residents from the ""Lac des oiseaux"" impoverished area, located just south of Skikda, tried to force entry into the Abderrezak Bouhara hospital. They threw Molotov cocktails and rocks on the building before local police forces stopped them. The cause of the assault was that these residents were not chosen for a new social housing project in the area.
On Nov 5, a number of residents of Douar Zahraoua protested against local authorities for their poor living conditions, asking for electricity.
On Nov 5 and 9, the Algerian army reportedly detonated several IEDs of unknown origin in Tebessa.

On Nov 6, several protests took place in the Bouira wilaya. In the city of Bouira, two protests were conducted. One was denouncing delays in social housing projects; the other one was denouncing alleged fraud with public funds allocated to social projects.

On Nov 6, several protests took place in the Bouira wilaya. Near Lakhdaria, a large number of protesters blocked the highway as they were trying to reach Algiers but were stopped by gendarmerie forces. They were individuals called upon to fight in the 1990s, asking the state to look into medical conditions that developped during that time.

On Nov 7, residents from Souk n'Tlata in Tadmait staged a protest in front of the company building the Souk n'Tlata dam, asking for the company to fulfill its promise of relocating the people living in the area into new houses.

On Nov 7, more than 600 workers at the University of Algiers gathered in front of the university's main gate to protest against the non-payment of their salaries, holding the Secretary-General of the university as responsible.
On Nov 7, residents from the St Antoine neighbourhood of Oran staged a protest in the area, blocking traffic, following the collapse of their building's stairs. They asked the wali to relocate them.

On Nov 7, the Algerian army claimed to have arrested 5 elements that provided ""terrorist support"" in Tissemsilt and Boumerdes. Although the army used the term ""terrorist"", it did not provide further details about the affiliations of the people arrested.

On Nov 7, the Algerian army claimed to have arrested 5 elements that provided ""terrorist support"" in Tissemsilt and Boumerdes. Although the army used the term ""terrorist"", it did not provide further details about the affiliations of the people arrested.
On Nov 7, the Algerian army reportedly detonated two IEDs of unknown origin in Tizi Ouzou and Tipaza.
On Nov 7, the Algerian army reportedly detonated two IEDs of unknown origin in Tizi Ouzou and Tipaza.

On Nov 8, residents of Taxlent staged a protest in the city by closing a number of roads and closing all shops, asking the authorities the truth about a young man of the community that died while under custody the week before.
On Nov 8, the Algerian army claimed to have uncovered and destroyed a number of IEDs and other weapons of unknown origins near the Beni Fadhala commune in Batna.

On Nov 8, the Algerian army claimed that two ""terrorists"", Naili Osman and Tarmoun Ali, handed themselves in in Djanet. Although the army used the term ""terrorist"", it did not provide further details about their affiliations.

On Nov 8, the Algerian army claimed that a ""terrorist"", Filali Bilal (aka Abou Ayman Thabet), handed himself in with 12 other people in Skikda. Although the army used the term ""terrorist"", it did not provide further details about his affiliations but explained that he had joined armed groups in 1998.

On Nov 9, residents from the Tenweych neighbourhood on the outskirts of Algiers blocked the road de l'espoir linking the capital city to 6 wilayas with burning tires to denounce the absence of electricity in their neighbourhood. Police intervened ands light clashes ensued.
On Nov 9, the Algerian army reportedly detonated four IEDs of unknown origin in Boumerdes and Medea.
On Nov 9, the Algerian army reportedly detonated four IEDs of unknown origin in Boumerdes and Medea.
On Nov 10, a number of female students from the Nour Bachir campus, located just outside of Al Bayadh city, stage a protest to denounce poor living conditions with a lack of security.

On Nov 10, a number of residents from the ""Lac des oiseaux"" impoverished area, located just south of Skikda, stage a protest in a nearby neighbourhood to denounce the fact that they were not chosen for a new social housing project in the area.

On Nov 11, dozens of residents from the Zeribet Hamed area, located 30 km north of El Faidh in Biskra, blocked a road linking their village to the Kenchela wilaya with burning tires, trunks and rocks to denounce their marginalisation by the regional government.

On Nov 11, a number of unemployed residents from the Bir El Ater region held a gathering near the phosphate mine in the area asking for employment in the form of permanent contracts instead of temporary work opportunities.
On Nov 11, the Algerian army claimed to have uncovered and destroyed a ""terrorist bunker"" and a number of IEDs in Blida and Ain Defla.
On Nov 11, the Algerian army claimed to have uncovered and destroyed a ""terrorist bunker"" and a number of IEDs in Blida and Ain Defla.

On Nov 11, residents who had benefited from social housings in the El Mohgoun area in September held a protest in front of the daira of Arzew to complain for not having been delivered their houses yet.
On Nov 12, more than 120 maintenance engineers held a protest in front of the Air Algeria HQs in Dar el Baida.

On Nov 12, around 200 residents from the El Khroub daira stormed the city's town hall to meet with officials in charge of attributing social housings to discuss with them fears of corruption taking place in the process.

On Nov 12, residents of the Abdelmadjid Benrebiaa neighbourhood in Ain El Bay, located in the Constantine wilaya, staged a protest in front of the wali's office in Constantine to denounce their living conditions.

On Nov 12, residents of the Ouled El Hadef, Zendaoua and Ouled Mansour villages closed the road linking Setif to Beni Fouda and Djemila, without resorting to violence, to denounce the fact that their villages should have been attached to a naturel gas network months ago.
On 13 November, parents and children protested in fron of the prefecture in Mchedallah to call for a completion of works at the Freres Saraoui school.

On Nov 12, residents of Taxlent staged a protest in the city, asking the authorities the truth about a young man of the community that died while under custody on Nov 1. A similar protest had already taken place on Nov 8.

On both Nov 13 and 14, residents of the Al Mahser village closed the road linking Ain Bessem to Souk Lekhmis, without resorting to violence, to denounce the fact that their village should have been attached to a naturel gas network in 2016.
On Nov 13, the Algerian army claimed to have uncovered and detonated 6 IEDs of unknown origin in Medea.
On 13 November, protesters from Shouhada, Iferki, shut down the prefecture in Tadmait to call for the swift provision of promised social housing units.

On Nov 13, as police and football fans clashed in the July 5th Stadium in Algiers, a video ciculated of policemen aggresively beaten up an isolated fan who had not shown any signs of violent behaviour.

On Nov 13, violence erupted at the July 5th Stadium in Algiers following a football match between the MCA and the UMSB. A total of 18 policemen and 22 supporters were injured, while 42 supporters were arrested.

On both Nov 13 and 14, residents of the Al Mahser village closed the road linking Ain Bessem to Souk Lekhmis, without resorting to violence, to denounce the fact that their village should have been attached to a naturel gas network in 2016.
On Nov 14, seven guards of the Mimosas State housing project in Staoueli assaulted and beat up journalist Houria Hamdaoui as she was covering a story on the expulsion of 55 former MPs from Mimosas.
On Nov 15, residents from a dozen of villages in the Attouche region staged a protest in front of Makouda's wali's office to denounce the poor state of the roads in this area.

On Nov 15, dozens of residents of Ain El Hadjar held a protest in front of the wali's office in Bouira to contest the list of 100 individuals who had been chosen to benefit from a social housing programme.
On Nov 15, merchants from the Guessab market in Blida held a protest in front of the wali's office to denounce a recent urbanism measure that built a wall adjacent to the market without consultation.
In the week of Nov 12, reports emerged that an IED exploded some time during the previous week near Bir El Atar, injuring two people.
On Nov 15, the Algerian army claimed to have uncovered and detonated 13 IEDs of unknown origin in Medea, Tlemcen and Tamanrasset.
On Nov 15, the Algerian army claimed to have uncovered and detonated 13 IEDs of unknown origin in Medea, Tlemcen and Tamanrasset.
On Nov 15, the Algerian army claimed to have uncovered and detonated 13 IEDs of unknown origin in Medea, Tlemcen and Tamanrasset.
On Nov 15, violence erupted in Bab El Oued after a football match between the USMA and the CSC. Large material damage was reported while 10 policemen were injured and 30 supporters arrested.
A group of three men blocked the car of the attorney of Ksar Chellala court and assaulted him and his companion. There were arrested the next day.
Nov 17-22, some residents of Souk El Khemis protested on the CW15 road for more than a week to denounce deteriorating living conditions.
On Nov 18, the Algerian army claimed to have arrested 4 elements that provided ""terrorist support"" in Boumerdes, Chlef and Tiaret.
On Nov 18, students of Bejaia University forcibly closed the gate of the Targa Ouezmour campus to denounce the expulsion of 34 students known to be politically active from the university.
On Nov 18, women residents from Oran staged a protest in front of the wali's office to denounce the time allocating them social housings is taking. Some of them first applied in 1995.

On Nov 18, students of Bejaia University stormed the HQs of the direction of university affairs in El Kseur to denounce the expulsion of 34 students known to be politically active from the university.

On Nov 18, local merchants clashed with police in the city of Bouira after police forces removed informal stands in the popular 140 logements neighbourhood. 6 merchants were arrested and no injuries were reported.
On 18 November, social housing beneficiaries from Ben Salah protested in front of the prefecture in Ammal to call for a swift completion of promised social housing units.
Nov 17-22, some residents of Souk El Khemis protested on the CW15 road for more than a week to denounce deteriorating living conditions.
On Nov 18, some residents of Sidi Amar protested on the RN14 going to Tiaret as the wali was going to the neighbouring Sidi Bakhti area over living conditions.
On Nov 18, the Algerian army claimed to have arrested 4 elements that provided ""terrorist support"" in Boumerdes, Chlef and Tiaret.
On Nov 18, the Algerian army claimed to have arrested 4 elements that provided ""terrorist support"" in Boumerdes, Chlef and Tiaret.

column16: El Watan (Algeria); Le Quotidien d'Oran; TSA Algerie
column17: On Nov 18, clashes were reported between Algerian military forces and ""terrorists"" in the area of Chaabat El Madbouh, in the Hamma Bouziane commune of Constantine. 3 ""terrorists"" and 1 soldier were killed.

On 19 November, police forces clashed with rioting informal vendors after police tried to confiscate their belongings. Police used teargas and rioters diverse objects. Twelve rioters were injured in the clashes.
On 19 November, protesters from the cite GMS shut down the prefecture of Akbou to call for better infrastructure in the cite.
Nov 17-22, some residents of Souk El Khemis protested on the CW15 road for more than a week to denounce deteriorating living conditions.

On Nov 19, a number of students held a protest in the Ahmed Hammani Zerzara campus of Mentouri university area to call for the traffic to be slowed down around the campus, after a student was killed by a car three days before.
On Nov 19, clashes were reported between Algerian military forces and ""terrorists"" in the area of El Grarem in Mila. 1 ""terrorist"" was killed.
On Nov 19, women residents from El Khroub staged a protest in front of the wali's office to denounce the time allocating them social housings is taking. Some of them first applied in 2011.
Nov 17-22, some residents of Souk El Khemis protested on the CW15 road for more than a week to denounce deteriorating living conditions.

On Nov 20, a police officer reportedly assaulted a hand-cuffed student in a police station of Bejaia, after the student had been arrested while protesting for the release of blogger Merzoug Touati, jailed since January 2017.

On Nov 20, police forces brutally dispersed a student demonstration for the release of blogger Merzoug Touati, jailed since January 2017, in front of the Targa Ouezmour campus of Bejaia University. Nearly all students, several dozens, were arrested and released the same day.

On Nov 20, a protest was held on the Said Makbel square of Bejaia calling for the release of blogger Merzoug Touati, jailed since January 2017. A number of students joined the demonstration after they were released following arrest during a similar protest earlier in the day in the Targa ouezmour campus of Bejaia University.

column7: UNPEF: National Union of Education and Training Employees; Teachers (Algeria); Labour Group (Algeria)
column17: On 21 November, teachers from a primary school in Toujda, affiliated with the UNPEF, protested to show support with colleagues who call for the provision of housing for teachers.

On 21 November, students at the Tamda campus of the Mouloud-Mammeri university of Tizi Ouzou shut down the rectorate to denounce the bad conditions at the university. Students blocked the campus for more than two weeks. Events coded on 21 November 28 November and 3 December.
On Nov 21, the Algerian army claimed to have uncovered and detonated IEDs belonging to ""terrorist groups"" of unknown origin in Batna, Skikda and Mila.

On Nov 21, a number of teachers from the wilaya of Constantine gathered to its eponym capital to protest against the firing of a fellow teacher after she denounced corruption within the school she was the director of.
On Nov 21, some residents of Belkheir blocked the RN17 road going to Mostaganem as the wali was going to the neighbouring Mohammadia area, to make their demands about living conditions heard.
On Nov 21, the Algerian army claimed to have uncovered and detonated IEDs belonging to ""terrorist groups"" of unknown origin in Batna, Skikda and Mila.
On Nov 21, the Algerian army claimed to have uncovered and detonated IEDs belonging to ""terrorist groups"" of unknown origin in Batna, Skikda and Mila.
Nov 17-22, some residents of Souk El Khemis protested on the CW15 road for more than a week to denounce deteriorating living conditions.
On Nov 21, about 50 people working in the education sector staged a protest in front of the wali's office of Msila to denounce a recent public policy.
On 22 November, protesters from Shouhada, Iferki, shut down the prefecture in Tadmait to call for the swift provision of promised social housing units.
On 22 November, protesters from Ait Aissa Mimoun shut down the prefecture with tires and tree trunks to call for the revision of a published social housing list.
On Nov 22, the Algerian army claimed to have uncovered and detonated 15 IEDs of unknown origin in the locality of Ras Bouragache in Skikda.
On Nov 22, the Algerian army claimed to have arrested ""terrorist"" Hamou Salah Abderrahman as he handed himself to military authorities in Adrar.

In the week of November 19th, students continued to block entrance to the Targa Ouezmour campus of Bejaia University to denounce the expulsion of 34 students known to be politically active from the university. The students were said to have remained on strike between November 18-25th. Coded as two events on November 18th and 22nd.
Nov 17-22, some residents of Souk El Khemis protested on the CW15 road for more than a week to denounce deteriorating living conditions.
On Nov 23, the Algerian army claimed to have arrested ""terrorist"" Benacer Mohammed in Tighenif.
On 24 November, protesters from Shouhada, Iferki, continued with the closue of the prefecture in Tadmait to call for the swift provision of promised social housing units.

On Nov 24, around 30 people protested in front of the Mahieddine Bachtarzi theatre in Algiers to call for the liberation of comedian Kamel Bouakaz, former football player Fodil Dob and singer Reda City 16, who have been incarcerated for about a month.
On Nov 24, the Algerian army claimed to have seized a weapons cache of unidentified origin in Bordj Badji Mokhtar at the border with Mali.

On Nov 25, around a hundred residents from the Meskine ghetto in Oued el Had neighbourhood of Constantine stormed the daira to ask for a complete relocation of the residents out of the ghetto. Instead, everytime a family leaves today, a new one arrives, perpetuating the issue of overcrowding.

On Nov 25, residents from the Loudha plateau staged a protest in front of the HQs of the local authority in Bouzeguene, preventing the staff from entering, to denounce the living conditions in the plateau.

column7: UNPEF: National Union of Education and Training Employees; Teachers (Algeria)
column17: On Nov 25, teachers of the UNPEF staged a protest in front of the direction of education in Khenchela to denounce, among other things, unpaid salaries.

On Nov 25, a number of journalists, human rights activists and politicians gathered in front of the Taher Djaout Press House, in El Hamma neighbourhood of Algiers, in commemoration of fellow journalist Mohamed Cherak who died on Nov 17 of a natural cause. They also used the occasion to protest against the poor working conditions of journalists in the country.
